courses.description: The course introduces students to major social and cultural issues in present-day Japan. It explores the important debates, problems, and challenges that have shaped Japanese society and culture in recent decades. The course encourages students to think critically about issues in Japanese society from a variety of disciplinary perspectives.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken JASP1020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- state, recognize, recall and tell the main features of postwar Japan. Participants are expected to analyze the challenges faced by postwar and contemporary Japan and how they were surmounted successfully.
- recognize, describe and clarify the strengths and weaknesses, the advantages and disadvantages of the features and characteristics of contemporary Japan.
- compare and contrast Japanese developmental phases in the postwar years.
- apply, relate and deepen their appreciation of the significance of the dynamics and interaction of selected Japanese political, social, environmental, demographic developments. Deepen their appreciation of the significance of major developments within Japan. Deepen their appreciation of the significance of the dynamics of Japan’s domestic society, economy and politics; its interaction with its neighboring region and the rest of the world; examine Japan’s coping mechanisms in interacting with globalization and major recent world trends.
- analyze Japan's structure, policies, economy, society and current trends. Analyze the causes and effects of internal and external influences on Japan's development. Analyze the challenges that Japan faces, its ways of managing them and the resulting innovative features. Develop analytical frameworks for these analyses.
- generalize, reflect and hypothesize their own conclusions with regards to the course materials and contemporary issues
[Writing skills]
Through the graded short essay exercise required in the course, class participants develop skills in essay-writing and library research such as literature review and analytical skills. It is also an opportunity for participants to put their creative ideas in writing.
[Interactive skills]
Class participation and attendance facilitates interactions with other class participants, learning from each other and exploring alternative viewpoints. The graded tutorials enhances interactions with other class participants, learning from each other and exploring alternative viewpoints through oral presentations that include class discussions and debates. Subject to availability, guest lectures may also be possible as opportunities for class participants to interact with individuals with specific relevant expertise.
[Reading skills]
While lectures and tutorials are the main modes of knowledge exchange and learning activity, students are encouraged to critically examine the required readings and present their alternative viewpoints and comments in the tutorials.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Background introduction (History)
Readings:
(1) Gordon, Andrew, "Global Power in a Polarized World: Japan in the 1980s" in A Modern History of Japan From Tokugawa Times to the Present (NY and Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2003, pp. 291-309 (18 Pages)
Tutorial:
The first tutorial will go through the requirements of the course. The first lecture will have an introduction of the course, how the participants are evaluated, the reading materials used
======================================================================
Week 2: An Era Beyond Recovery (History)
Readings:
(1) Gordon, Andrew, "Beyond the Postwar Era" in A Modern History of Japan From Tokugawa Times to the Present (NY and Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2003, pp. 310-332 (22 Pages)
Tutorial:
Class participants will work in groups to discuss their understanding of the readings and learn to adopt the perspective of their training, expertise and interest to analyze the readings, ask questions and discuss it in the context of their research interests.
=================================================================
Week 3: A Brave New Decade for Japan (History)
Readings:
(1) McClain, James L., "Chapter 17 Another New Century" in Japan: A Modern History, (NY and London: WW Norton and Company), 2002, pp. 599-632 (33 Pages)
Tutorial:
It plans to discuss early in the course broad strategies to tackle the short essay and build on essay writing skills learnt in other modules and courses, discussing thesis statement writing skills and question writing skills for the purpose of enhancing essay writing skills. Mid-term to be discussed, sample papers distributed for early reference. Discussion on research essay also includes items like thesis statement/hypothesis; important issues and research questions for inclusion in their essays and a table of contents. Opportunities are provided for class participants to ask questions on how to tackle the essay. Learn to cite sources and conduct library research.
===============================================================
Week 4: The Study of a Classic Popular Culture Icon in the age of Globalization (Popular Culture)
Readings:
(1) Shiraishi, Saya S., "Doraemon Goes Abroad" in Japan Pop!: Inside the world of Japanese popular culture (edited by Timothy J. Craig) (NY: East Gate), 2000, pp. 288-289
Tutorial:
Review readings in class covered up to this point of time in preparation for the mid-term. Participants get into groups to debate and take sides on crucial issues in the mandatory readings, in the process, identifying crucial issues and challenges in defending their viewpoints against contravening arguments. Discussions on what students think are possible mid-term exams if they designed the exam.
================================================================
Week 5: A Contemporary Japanese Popular Cultural Icon Captures the World (Popular Culture)
Readings:
(1) Allison, Anne, “Gotta Catch ‘Em All”: The Pokemonization of America (and the World)” and “Epilogue” in Millennial Monsters (Berkeley, LA and London: University of California Press), 2006, pp. 234-280. (46 pages) Divided into two lectures
Tutorial
A session to review readings in class covered up to this point of time in preparation for the mid-term. Participants get into groups to debate and take sides on crucial issues in the mandatory readings, in the process, identifying crucial issues and challenges in defending their viewpoints against contravening arguments.
==============================================================
Week 6: Pokemon in the age of Globalization (Popular Culture)
Readings: (Continued)
(1) Allison, Anne, “Gotta Catch ‘Em All”: The Pokemonization of America (and the World)” and “Epilogue” in Millennial Monsters (Berkeley, LA and London: University of California Press), 2006, pp. 234-280. (46 pages)
Tutorial:
Mid-term exam
===============================================================
Week 7: Robots in Popular Culture (Popular Culture and Technology)
Readings:
(1) Hornyak, Timothy N., "Chapter 6 Humanoids at home", in Loving the Machine the Art and Science of Japanese Robots (Tokyo, NY, London: Kodansha), 2006, pp. 85-100 (15 pages)
Tutorial:
Class participants get together in groups to go through a critical analysis of readings covered in the class up to this point of time, class participants will identify, categorize and compartmentalize major arguments while formulating a theme for their respective teams in preparation for class presentation. Sample final papers given out. Comparative exercises in class.

Week 8: Gender
Readings:
(1) Jackson, Keith and Miyuki Tomoioka, "Section 3: Constraints to Women's Career Choices" in The Changing Face of Japanese Management (London and NY: Routledge), 2004, pp. 103-112 (9 pages)

Week 9: Japan in the World (Cultural Soft Power)
Readings:
(1) Tsutsui, William M., “Japan as Soft Superpower” in Japanese Popular Culture and Globalization (Ann Arbor: Association for Asian Studies Inc.), 2010, pp. 59-69.

Short class presentation in groups. Class participants get together in groups to go through a critical analysis of readings covered in the class up to this point of time, class participants will identify, categorize and compartmentalize major arguments while formulating a theme for their respective teams in preparation for class presentation. courses.title: Japanese Culture and Society
courses.description: (UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100.) The main objective of this course is to give students a general idea of Japanese cultural history and social background of modern Japan. Guidance leading to a better understanding of Japan will be provided.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for Japanese Studies Majors or students who have taken UGEC1232
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the main areas of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, and religion. They are expected to understand the ways in which Japanese see their own society in terms of economic growth,
Japan
's place in the world, social order, and political structure.
2) Students are expected to understand and be able to use a variety of social theories and perspectives in understanding
Japan
. They are also expected to have gained an understanding of how these same perspectives might be used to analyze their own society, or other societies which they may wish to study in the future.
3) Students are expected to develop a clearer understanding of their own values regarding work, leisure, marriage, family, love, and religion through a comparison with the debates and competing interpretations of these values in
Japan
.
Remarks:
Department Board members disagreed with the suggestion that they replace the word 'understanding' with another word such as 'identity, explain, analyze or synthesize' as suggested by UGE.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Images of
Japan
This lesson introduces students to widespread popular images of
Japan
in Asian and Western media and academia. It considers how and why these images have changed over time and asks students to consider the usefulness and limits of generalizations about other people and societies.
Week 2: Nation, Nationalism and the Imperial System
This lesson introduces students to theories explaining nationalism. It then uses these theories to consider nationalism in
Japan
. It explores the Japanese Imperial system in the context of historical developments in Japanese nationalism.

Week 3: The "Economic Miracle"
This lesson explores two main theories behind
Japan
's economic development and subsequent recession of the 1990s. It considers the reasons for
Japan
's economic success, the experience of this success for Japanese people, and asks students to consider competing interpretations of
Japan
's economic development.

This lesson introduces several theories regarding the family in modem society. It then explores changes in Japanese family forms over time. Students are asked to articulate their own values toward love, marriage, and family in contrast to what they are learning about

Week 9: Leisure and Play
This lesson explores the role of leisure in modem societies and the development of the concept and practices of leisure in modem
Japan
. Leisure in
Japan
is explored in terms of gender, age, class, and generational differences. Students are encouraged to articulate their own attitudes toward leisure in relation to work, to consider how perceptions of how leisure have changed over time in their society, and to discuss how they expect their own leisure practices will change
as

This lesson explores the development of mass culture in
Japan
and explains the ways in which popular culture may serve as the basis for both social change and the reproduction of the status quo. Students are asked to consider how their own participation in popular culture and mass culture both generates changes in their societies and reproduces global capitalist structures.

Students are urged to develop their own interpretations of the role of religion in modern societies and in their own lives.

Week 13: Conclusion
This lesson reviews the social issues which Japanese consider to be most serious such as the emergence of diversity, subcultures, and changing youth expectations and desires regarding adulthood. It discusses, through surveys, how Japanese people view their society and how they view their future. It asks students to consider which problems are seen as the most critical in their societies, how their own societies view their future, and how popular views about their societies and about their societies' future are related to the beliefs held by individuals.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Understanding Japanese Languages and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120.) This course explores the relationship between Japanese language and culture. Everyday communication strategies adopted by people in Japanese society will be examined in terms of Japanese language expressions, styles and structures. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course but interdisciplinary approaches will also be adopted. This course is designed for students who are interested in knowing more about Japan but who have very limited or no knowledge of the Japanese language. Student will gain an understanding of the basic structure of the Japanese language, learn how usage of the language reflects Japanese culture and behavior, and explore how communication patterns of Japanese speakers differ from speakers of other languages.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to have gained a basic understanding of the structure of the Japanese language and historical changes of the writing system. Moreover, students will be able to understand the usage of the language, different styles and when each should be used, and different strategies used in expressing politeness.
2. Students are expected to understand the relationship between the language expressions and the behaviors of Japanese people in various circumstances and the reasons behind such behaviors.
3. Through comparing the culture of
Japan
with that of
Hong Kong
, students will become able to make comments on the characteristics of each and distinguish between the two.
4. Students will be able to perform an elementary study regarding Japanese culture and this will help the students to develop his/her further study in Japanese Studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
Lesson 1
Introduction to Japanese culture
:
This lesson explains how Japanese culture influences daily life in
Hong Kong
today. The usage and the characteristics of Japanese language will also be discussed.
Week 2
Lesson 2
Introduction to the historical changes of kanji and kana in the Japanese language
:
This lesson explains the historical changes of kanji and kana in Japanese language. Focus will be on why Japanese absorbed Chinese characters into their writing system and the process of how Chinese characters were converted to the modern
kana (hiragana and katakana)
.
Week 3 – Week 4
Lesson 3
Introduction to the phrases expressing linguistic politeness
:
This lesson briefly explains the phrases expressing linguistic politeness. These include honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.
Week 4 - 5
Lesson 4
Strategies used in making requests and refusals in Japanese
:
This lesson discusses how Japanese make requests and refuse the requests of others. Such expressions are often used in daily life by Japanese but are not easily understood by foreigners. Special attention will be given to:
a. the difference in behaviour between Japanese and non Japanese in making requests and refusals.
b. how this behaviour reflects characteristics of Japanese culture.
Week 6 – Week 7
Lesson 5
Strategies used in making apologies and taking responsibility
:
This lesson discusses how Japanese apologize and take responsibility after misconduct such as scandals or accidents. For example, we often see the top management of Japanese companies bow to the public to apologize for their misconduct and they may even quit the company in order to take responsibility for problems. In
Hong Kong
, it is rare to see such a phenomenon. We will discuss the mechanism of how Japanese make an apology and the effect of the Japanese way of apologizing upon social situations. Special attention will be given to the comparison of the styles of apology in Japanese and
Hong Kong
societies. We will also discuss the relationship between the Japanese way of apologizing and issues related to the Sino-Japanese War.
Week 8 – Week 9
Lesson 6
Ambiguity in the Javanese language
:
Compared with other languages such as Chinese, there are many ambiguous linguistic practices in Japanese. These include, for example, the deletion of the subject "
watashi
" (I), the use of "
koto ni
narimashita
" (become something) rather than "
koto ni shimashita
" (I decided to do something) when talking about personal matters such as getting married, and the frequent use of intransitive verbs rather than transitive verbs. Most Japanese language learners including
Hong Kong
learners have experienced difficulties with these expressions and practices in their learning process. We will analyze and comment on this phenomenon.
Week 9 – Week 10
Lesson 7
The Business Manner of Japanese
:
This lesson discusses how Japanese behave in business negotiations. Japanese are often criticized for not stating their true feelings and opinions. They often use expressions such as "
kangaesasetekudasai
" (Please let me think about it), "
kekkoo desu
" (It's O.K. /No, thank you) to indirectly express their opinions. We will discuss why Japanese behave in such a way and the correct way to deal with a Japanese business partner.
Week 10 - Week 11
Lesson 8
Japanese language in a sociolinguistic perspective
:
In this lesson we discuss the following items of importance in sociolinguistics as they appear in the Japanese language.
a. the comparison between written and colloquial styles
b. the comparison of language usage for men and women
c. the comparison between the standard language and dialect
d. the comparison of language usage between the young and the elderly
e. the comparison between formal styles and informal styles
f. the comparison between jargon and standard expressions
Week 12
Lesson 9
The success and failure in learning Javanese language (with a focus on
Hong Kong
Cantonese speaking learners)
:
First, we will give a brief introduction to the theories of second language acquisition. Next, the factors affecting the results of the process of second language learning will be discussed. To ensure a better understanding, case studies comparing English language acquisition among Japanese and
Hong Kong
people will be introduced. Finally, by summarizing the above observations and the characteristics of both Japanese and Cantonese, we will comment on the difficulties experienced by Hong Kong Cantonese speaking Japanese learners.
Week 13
Lesson 10
Special topics on Japanese 1anguage and Japanese culture
:
Special topics will be selected to help students understand the relationship between Japanese language and culture.
a.
"shin go ryuukoogo taishoo"
(New words and buzz terms Grand Prix)
b.
"kotoshi no kanji"
(The Chinese character of this year)

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Understanding Japanese Culture and Society Through Movies

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description: (UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140.) Film is always regarded as an important medium for understanding society and culture. This course looks into the formation and characteristics of Japanese mentality and behaviour, through Japanese movies and academic readings of Japanese studies. This course consists of two major parts: 1) Lesson 2 to Lesson 7: Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies; 2) Lesson 8 to Lesson 12: Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. The lecturer will commence each lesson by referring to various academic readings, and will show movie clips if necessary, to serve as the basis for in-class discussions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GESC2080 or UGEC1302
courses.learning_outcomes:
Ø
Be able to understand the Japanese mentality and behaviour.
Ø
Acquire the ability to examine and investigate the academic and cultural meanings of movies from a macroscopic – cross-border, cross-era, interdisciplinary – perspective.
Ø
Be able to extract and digest messages carried in movies, in order to obtain a more thorough understanding of the relationships between Japan and other countries, including China, Korea and America.
Ø
Acquire a more thorough understanding of the influence of Japanese culture.
Ø
Further develop their critical thinking, presentation and writing skills through interactive teaching methods such as discussions, classwork and essay writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson 1
Introduction
(課程介紹)
This lesson introduces the objectives and learning approach of this course.
Part 1 (Lesson 2 to Lesson 7)
Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies
(從電影看日本人的自我觀
)
This part brings out different predominant theories on Japanese mental structure, and discusses whether they can be applied to the Japanese mentality revealed in Japanese movies produced from the post-war period to present, so as to investigate the degree of their validity.
Lesson 2
Japanese Hierarchy and
Bushido
(日本的階級觀念與武士道)
This lesson discusses the function of hierarchy in Japanese society, and the important role of
bushido
in establishing the traditional Japanese ideals of conduct.
Readings:
Kurosawa-Film Studies and Japanese Cinema
, and《武士道》
Lesson 3
Japanese Moral Standards and the Shame Culture
(日本道德觀與恥的文化)
This lesson compares the Japanese shame culture to the guilt culture by investigating the relationship between groupism and individualism in Japan, and sees how it shapes the Japanese moral standards.
Readings:
The Anatomy of Dependence,
and《日本倫理思想與日本現代化》
Lesson 4
Passive Individualism Among the Youth
(日本新一代的被動個人主義)
This lesson examines the difference between individualism in Japanese new generation’s view of love and that of traditional thinking, and investigates the profound influences of Japanese movies and television culture on young people.
Readings:
The Creative Edge: Emerging Individualism in Japan
“Transcending the Outsider’s Role: A Japanese Superstar in Japan and Hong Kong”
,
and
Lesson 5
Japan’s Return to Asia: Political Meaning Behind the Boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro
(金城武熱潮的形成和意義)
This lesson discusses the transformation of Japanese identification of being Asian from the Meiji Westernization to the age of globalization, by examining the political meaning behind the boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro in the 1990s.
Reading: “Facing Challenges in a New Age: A Multicultural and New Generation Identity for Japan, through Kaneshiro Takeshi and Kubotsuka Yōsuke”
Lesson 6-7
A New Stage in Japan-China and Japan-Korea Relationships
(對中和對韓的日本新觀)
This lesson analyzes the new views on China and Korea revealed in Japanese movies produced from the 1990s to present.
Readings:
Interpreting History in Sino-Japanese Relations
, and 《東亞三國的近現代史》
Part 2 (Lesson 8 to Lesson 12)
Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others
(
比較日本與其他民族集團的思維模式
)
Through the comparison between movies of Japan and other nations, this part focuses on the different thinking patterns of Japan and others.
Lesson 8
Japanese Self-Deprecation and Male Chauvinism
(日本自嘲文化與男尊女卑)
Through the comparison of comedies of Japan and America, this lesson investigates the unique culture of self-deprecation, and the different roles of men and women in Japan.
Readings:
Beyond Common Sense: Sexuality and Gender in Contemporary Japan
, and
Different Games Different Rules - Why American and Japanese Misunderstand Each Other
.
Lesson 9
The Logic and Influence of
Amae
(“依愛”的邏輯與影響)
This lesson discusses how
amae
(dependence) affects the Japanese logical thinking and behaviour by comparing suspense movies of Japan, Hong Kong and Korea.
Readings: “
Higaisha-ishiki
: The Psychology of Revolting Youth in Japan,” 《日本的自我：社會心理學家論 日本人》及〈《花樣奇緣》呈現的日本人精神面貌〉
Lesson 10
Imaged Masculinity and the Aesthetics of Violence
(男性想像與暴力美學)
This lesson investigates the meaning of
ninjo
(human feelings) and
giri
(obligation), and the relationship between Japanese
yakuza
culture and gangster films. It also compares the different points of view of Takeshi Kitano and Quentin Tarantino in presenting the “aesthetics of violence” and “tragic hero”.
Readings:
The Chrysanthemum and the Sword: Patterns of Japanese Culture,
and
Myth and
Masculinity in the Japanese Cinema: Towards a Political Reading of the “Tragic Hero”.
Lesson 11
Self and Others: A Comparison of Japanese and American
Godzillas
(日美哥斯拉呈現的 “我” 與“他”)
This lesson investigates the socio-political meanings of
Godzilla
in Japan, and looks into the different viewpoints on the concepts of “others” between Japanese and American monster films.
Readings:
Hibakusha Cinema: Hiroshima, Nagashima, Nagasaki, and the Nuclear Image in Japanese Film
;
and
“From
Godzilla
to
Train Man:
A Study of the Japanese Self Image in the Context of the West”
Lesson 12
Cinderella & Women Warrior: A Comparison of Disney and Miyazaki’s Heroines
(比較日美動畫中的女性形象)
This lesson investigates the Japanese national spirit revealed in animations, compares the different images of female characters in Hayao Miyazaki’s and Disney’s animations, and examines their different cultural significance.
Readings:
Mouse Morality: The Rhetoric of Disney Animated Film,
and
Anime from Akira to Princess Mononoke: Experiencing Contemporary Japanese Animation
Lesson 13
Mid-Term Report Review and Conclusion
(中期報告成績討論與課程總結)
A follow-up discussion of the mid-term reports submitted by students; and a general review
of the topics, discussions and materials covered in the course, and helps students to
prepare for the final examination.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Popular Culture in Cultural Globalization
courses.description: (UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160.)  This course examines the development and academic significance of various forms of Japanese popular culture such as films, comics, music, TV dramas and culinary culture, from multidisciplinary perspectives, including history, cultural anthropology, cultural studies and media studies. It aims to deepen understanding the following three facets of Japanese popular culture:1) the applicaton of cultural globalization theory in Japan; 2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries; and 3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Using concrete examples and grounding on representative academic writings, this course discusses the globalization of Japanese popular culture and relevant issues in indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows and media-mix. Students are trained to understand the nature and cultural implications of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context. Besides lectures, discussions and readings, this course selectively utilizes topical essays (projects), e-learning, audio-visual materials and fieldwork-based assignments as supplementary teaching tools.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken JASP1110 or UGEC1271
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through a historical and cultural analysis of different facets of Japanese popular culture, this course aims to achieve the following three academic goals:
1)
It aims to use Japanese popular culture as a medium or stepping stone to enhance students’ interest in and understanding of Japanese history, society and culture.
2)
It aims to deepen understanding of nature and impact of Japanese cultural industry and its cultural implications in an Asian context.
3)
It aims to discuss Japanese popular culture within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. Having taken this course, students will be equipped with a basic ability to analyse cultural phenomenon in the lens of such cultural concepts as indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows, media mix, cultural colonialism and orientalism.
courses.course_syllabus:
Main Objective
:
This main purpose of course is to examine the global popularization and localization of Japanese popular culture from historical, cultural and comparative perspectives within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. It aims to indicate that the cultural flows between
Japan
and
Asia
are by no means one-way traffic and
Asia
has been interacting and collaborating with the Japanese in creating, manufacturing, marketing and distributing cultural products for decades. Lectures, discussions and readings highlight different facets of cultural acculturation and transnational interaction found in Japan-Asia cross-cultural flows, such as appropriation, hybridization, global localization business strategy, the making of localized editions, the local application of Japanese formula, joint production, and the participation of foreign artists and staff. Solidly grounding on empirical data as well as theories from cultural globalization and cross-cultural studies, this course will be a pioneering teaching and learning project to explore uncharted research territories in Japanese studies, Japan-Hong Kong relations, and cultural studies.
Key Issues and Problems
:
The following key issues and problems regarding the globalization of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context will be addressed in this course within the theoretical fiarnework of cultural globalization:
1) The idea that the influx of Japanese cultural products is a form of cultural imperialism that aims to expand Japanese economic interest and to spread Japanese value and lifestyle in
Asia
will be empirically and theoretically reexamined and challenged. It shows that cultural imperialism is an outdated model in cross-cultural studies, because it fails to understand the dynamic mechanism in transnational cultural flows and cultural forces of localization and hybridization.
2) While using "glocalization" (Roland Robertson uses it to refer to the localization strategy employed by multi-national companies to promote their products in different nations) to investigate the global business strategy of Japanese companies such as Sony, Nintendo, Capcom and Bandai in Asian and global markets, this course underscores the limitation of the glocalization theory in the East Asian context, as it fails to see the initiative taken by Asian artists and businessmen to creatively and selectively domesticate Japanese elements.
3) This course uses Japanese popular culture as a mirror or text to decode social and cultural issues of contemporary
Japan
. For examples, themes about ethnicity, gender, social hierarchy, political ideology, and cultural identity will be examined in the lens of Japanese popular culture.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Modern Sino-Japanese Relations
courses.description: Sino-Japanese relations are an important dimension of the history of modern East Asia. This course analyzes this multifaceted relationship from the mid-19th century to the present day. It will pay special attention to such topics as mutual perception, territorial and historical disputes, immigration, boycotts and collaboration, cultural diplomacy, postwar rapprochement, and attempts to move into a new age of Sino-Japanese coexistence. A main theme of discussion will be the need for accommodation and cooperation despite continual tension between the two countries.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 德川時代在日之華人 (The Chinese in Tokugawa Japan)
本課探討德川時代日本華僑社會形成的背景、因素及過程，又考察長崎華僑融入日本社會，改變居住生活形態的發展，以及中國儒學對德川時期二元政治體制盛衰之影響。
2. 明治、大正時代在日之華人 (The Chinese in Meiji and Taisho Japan)
本課分析19世紀末即明治後期中國人留學日本潮流產生的背景、因素及具體情況，並探究大正時代留日潮流的反覆發展，以及留日學生的政治化趨勢。
3. 中日甲午戰爭 (1894-1895) (The First Sino-Japanese War 1894-1895)
本課分析甲午戰爭爆發的背景和始末、戰爭期間及以後清朝對日觀念的變化，以及戰後的中日關係
發展。
4. 在清朝民國之日本人 (The Japanese in Qing and Republican China)
本課探討甲午戰爭前日本人在華的情報活動和戰爭前後日本人在華經營的通信報刊活動。
5. 日本對華之文教政策 (The Japanese Cultural and Education Policy towards China)
本課考察近代日本在華文教活動的產生及發展、各種教育活動的內容，以及二次大戰期間日本在學校推行的同化教育。
6. 華人的反日與附日 (The Chinese Resistance and Collaboration with the Japanese)
本課一方面探討民初、五四運動時期中國教科書的反日思想、1928年五三慘案以後的反日運動，另一方面分析抗日戰爭期間附日勢力出現的原因，諸勢力的類型、活動以及日本招攬漢奸的政策。
7. 二戰後在日之華人I (The Chinese in Postwar Japan I)
本課探討二次大戰以後至今日本華僑的人數增長情況、中華街華僑的經濟事業發展，以及新一代華僑的經濟結構變化。
8. 二戰後在日之華人II (The Chinese in Postwar Japan II)
本課考察二次大戰以後至今日本新舊數代華僑的不同程度同化情況，又探討
戰後華僑學校的教育問題及華僑的婚姻觀念演變。
9. 駐華之日本外交官 (The Japanese Diplomat on China)
本課說明駐華日本國總領事館包括在香港日本國總領事館的主要角色，指出日本領事充當促進中、日溝通、深化兩國關係的橋樑，並以近來數任在香港日本國總領事的訪問和演講，揭示近來日本的對華政策。
10. 中日的相互理解 (Mutual Perception between the Chinese and the Japanese)
本課考察在近、現代各階段中、日兩國的相互認識和觀感的演變發展及其諸發展跟兩國政治、外交、經濟、軍事等方面變化的互動關係，並探討近年中日兩國致力構築相互認識的平台的趨勢。
11. 日本與中國威脅論 (Japan and the ‘China Threat’ Theory)
本課考察1980年代至今中國的急速經濟發展及經貿策略演變，並分析90年代以來東亞國家經貿分工結構的轉變、中國跟東亞諸國尤其日本的經貿關係發展，以及日本先後產生「中國威脅論」和「中國機會論」的輿論變化。
12. 中日糾紛 (Sino-Japanese Disputes)
本課分析1990年代以來影響中、日兩國關係的國際環境和日本國內環境的種種變化，以及損害兩國關係的若干因素，包括日本政治右傾化問題、兩國的歷史觀衝突、靖國神社參拜問題、新「日美防衛合作指針」及台灣問題等等。
13. 中日關係的前景 (The future of Sino-Japanese Relations)
本課探討中、日兩國在亞洲地區共同化解衝突，協作發展的前景，如共同維持東亞地區的和諧穩定，促進該區的經濟互惠合作、安全和平及災難處理等發展方向。

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Tourism and Sustainable Development
courses.description: (UGEC1372 is double-coded with JASP1190.) Since 2015, tourism has been listed by the United Nations as one of the means to achieve sustainable development goals. How does tourism contribute to the sustainable development of human society? What are the impacts of tourism upon the cities and communities? Using Japan as a principal example, this course aims at examining the possibilities and challenges of achieving sustainable development goals through tourism. The first part of this course introduces basic concepts of tourism and sustainable development goals, and discusses their relationship. The second part of the course compares Japan to China and other countries, and investigates the benefits and costs of tourism in relation to sustainable cities and communities, indigenous culture, and natural resources. Additional discussions further explore the potentials of sustainable tourism in Hong Kong. With assigned readings and coursework, students are expected to acquire knowledge on sustainable development goals, and critically evaluate tourism as a means to achieve these goals.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part One – Overview
Week 01: Overview: Why Do People Travel? How Does Traveling Relate to Sustainable Development Goals?
This lecture topic introduces basic theories in social studies of tourism, and the current discussions on tourism in relation to sustainable development goals.
Week 02: Introduction to Sustainable Development Goals
This lecture topic further examines the UN Sustainable Development Goals, and requests students to discuss the possible challenges of achieving these goals through tourism.
Week 03: The Sustainable Destination
There is no tourism without destinations. This lecture topic examines features that make a destination sustainable.
Week 04: Overtourism? Cases of Kyoto, Macau and Venice
Overtourism is one of the keywords that address the problems incurred by tourism. Drawing cases from both Europe and Asia, this lecture topic examines these problems, and invites students to suggest solutions.
Part Two – Sustainable Development and Tourism in Japan and Beyond
Week 05: Overview of Tourism in Japan
This lecture topic introduces the socioeconomic background in the historical development of tourism in Japan. Drawing Japan as an example, students are encouraged to reflect on the social and political agenda of tourism.
Week 06: Gentrification: The Impacts of Urban Tourism
This lecture topic examines the problem of urban gentrification and its relation to tourism in Japan, China and beyond.
Week 07: Mega Events
Drawing on the Olympic Games as one of the examples, this lecture topic scrutinizes the effects and impacts of hosting mega events to attract tourists in Japan and beyond.
Week 08: Cultural Heritage and Local Communities
This lecture topic scrutinizes the impacts of tourism on local communities at world cultural heritage sites.
Week 09: Environment and Ecotourism
The lecture topic examines ecotourism and its impact on the local and global environment.
Week 10: Tourism and Indigenous Culture
This lecture topic investigates the role and impact of tourism on the sustainability of indigenous culture.
Week 11: Tourism and Rural Revitalization
This lecture topic focuses on the possibilities and challenges of introducing tourism for sustainable development in depopulating regions in Japan and beyond.
Week 12: Tourism and Disasters
This lecture topic discusses the phenomenon of transforming places associated with tragedy into tourist attractions, its cultural meanings, and social impacts upon local communities in Japan and beyond.
Week 13: Discussion: Sustainable Development and Tourism in Hong Kong and Japan
During the concluding lecture, students are invited to exchange their views on sustainable development in Hong Kong, in comparison to Japan and other localities discussed over the semester.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Language Tasting
courses.description: [This course is offered via asynchronous online mode. Students should register the course via KEEP, a CUHK eLearning platform where the course materials are uploaded.]This course aims to provide a ‘tasting’ opportunity for students who have no history of Japanese language learning before to start their first Japanese language learning. The topics in this course will cover pronunciation of ‘Kana’, simple daily life communication topics to express their favorite food, interest/hobby, shopping, places they want to go/things they want to do in Japan, etc. In order to have a better understanding of Japanese society, relevant Japanese cultural topics will also be included in this course. After completing this course, students will have basic knowledge of Japanese ‘Kana’ and be able to communicate in simple Japanese language with Japanese people on topics introduced in this course. For students who opt for further study in Japanese language, this course will provide a good foundation for them to have a smooth transition to the upcoming elementary course. On the other hand, for students who do not opt for further study, this course will also provide simple basic language knowledge for daily conversation with Japanese people while visiting Japan in the future.Students who have attended any one year exchange study programme in Japan and/or passed any level of Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPT) are NOT allowed to take this course.

courses.course_syllabus:
JAS1450 and 1460 are consecutive one-semester courses designed to provide comprehensive training in reading, listening, speaking and writing in Japanese at the elementary level for elective students with an emphasis on elementary grammar.
Students are required to attend four hours of language lessons per week and are expected to spend two hours on homework each week. Language lessons are conducted in four languages: Japanese, English, Cantonese and Mandarin. Teachers use various kinds of conversational practices based on natural conversation emphasizing the use of the language in context.
The examination papers are written in Chinese and Japanese, and it contains task(s) of Chinese to Japanese translation. Depending on the situation, an English translation of the Chinese texts can be provided for reference. However, in case there is any inconsistency or conflict in the translation between the Chinese and English texts, the Chinese version shall prevail.
After completing the courses, students are expected to reach novice-middle level, and continue to enrol in the intermediate level language courses.

courses.description: This course interrogates the major institutions, ideas and historical forces that shape life in contemporary Japan, and pushes students to examine the similarities and differences in processes of modernization across societies. As students have covered the historical and sociopolitical groundings of modern and contemporary Japan, this course goes deeper into the social science of Japan by examining the major social institutions of home, school, and work to facilitate our understandings of the primary forces of socialization and organization and the dynamics of power in contemporary Japanese social life. Furthermore, it addresses the new challenges emerging within each of these spheres based on Japan’s changing socio-economic and demographic landscapes. The study of Japan challenges us to reevaluate the premises of Western social theory as well as HK-centric conceptualization, and it rewards us with fresh understandings of the transformations to modernity and the nature and direction of modern life. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will be able to gain a broad grasp of how Japanese society as well as its broader issues are approached and analyzed.
Students will also be able to articulate thoughtful and well-founded opinions based on their understanding of course materials.
In addition, students will develop critical thinking skills, construct analytical essays, give PowerPoint presentations, and lead academic discussions.

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of basic research methods for independent field research. Research methods such as interviewing, questionnaires, participant observation, and media surveys will be introduced and the merits of each will be discussed. The course will teach students how to design a research project and write a research proposal. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will gain an understanding of the merits and limitations of a variety of qualitative research methods.
Students will be able apply selected social science methodology to design their own research project in Japan.

Enhance the understanding of Japan and Asia’s cultural industries; Gain updated information from experts in the industry.
Analysis cultural phenomenon in Asia’s Cultural and Creational Industries systematically with independent thoughts.
Discover concrete directions of development of HK’s Cultural and Creational Industries.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Introduction to Japanese Animation, Comic and Game
courses.description: Animation, comic and game (ACG) are perhaps the most globalized parts of Japanese popular culture. They have a very strong impact on global cultural industry and consumer culture, used by the Japanese companies to expand their economic activities overseas and by the Japanese government for cultural politics. This course examines issues relating to Japanese animation, comic and game from historical, sociological and comparative perspectives. In addition to lectures, this course promotes interactive teaching and learning by organizing group discussion, video session and panel discussion.
courses.course_syllabus:
PART 1: Introduction and Overview
Lecture 1: Introduction(1): What is ACG?
Lecture 2 & 3: The development of Animation Industry in Japan via “The Big Three Publisher”
PART 2: Animation Research
Lecture 4 & 5: Science Fiction Anime: Japanese “Five Kings”
Lecture 6: Otaku (1): Being the Bridge, or being abandoned?
Lecture 7: Otaku (2): Moe and Otaku
PART 3: Regional Comparative Study
Lecture 8: Game Industry : The development path between Japan and USA
PART 4: Regional Comparative Study
Lecture 9: ACG and Reality : 2.5 dimensions
Lecture 10: Sex and Gender (1) : The difference demand between two sexes for animation and games
Lecture 11: Sex and Gender (2) : Relationship between pornography and the development of Japanese ACG Industry
Lecture 12 :Review and prepare for the final exam

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Culture of Japanese Mass Media
courses.description: This course discusses the cultural and social implications of mass media in contemporary Japan. Media contexts in Japan are not only regarded as a business or an entertainment but also an ideology, or a remarkable source of soft power in the world's different media capitals. This course focuses on the construction of the Japanese mass media context in the age of internet and globalization, investigating how the media contexts are being produced and manipulated and how the influence is being demonstrated.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to understand the game of Japanese media, formation of Japanese image, ideology and illusion, global influence from Japanese media;
Students can analyze how the Japanese media influences our daily life

courses.course_syllabus:
JAS2450 and 2460 are consecutive one-semester courses designed to provide comprehensive training in reading, listening, speaking and writing in Japanese at the intermediate level for elective students with an emphasis on both comprehension and expression.
Students are required to attend four hours of language lessons per week and are expected to spend two hours on homework each week. Language lessons are conducted in four languages: Japanese, English, Cantonese and Mandarin. Teachers use various kinds of conversational practices based on natural conversation emphasizing the use of the language in context.
The examination papers are written in Chinese and Japanese, and it contains task(s) of Chinese to Japanese translation. Depending on the situation, an English translation of the Chinese texts can be provided for reference. However, in case there is any inconsistency or conflict in the translation between the Chinese and English texts, the Chinese version shall prevail.
After completing the courses, students are expected to reach the intermediate-low level of Japanese language ability.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Japan
courses.description: This course introduces the social scientific study of gender, sexuality, and family in Japan from the postwar to the contemporary period from a comparative perspective. As the course covers a lot of readings, writings, and discussions on the issues of gender and sexuality, students are expected to come to class prepared to discuss the readings and facilitate the class discussion. For many, Japan represents a sweeping stereotype of extreme gender norms vis-à-vis contemporary Euro-American gender norms and manifestations. Such stereotypes are employed not only by outsiders to critique the society ethnocentrically, but also by some natives as well. Both sides frequently comment on the ways gender and gendered expectations shape and even determine contemporary experiences of “being Japanese.” Furthermore, stereotypes about gender and sexuality in Japan frequently overlap with and draw from broader stereotypes about Japan vis-à-vis other Asian societies and Asian societies vis-à-vis Western societies.By identifying these stereotypes and also critically questioning what gender means and how it is being shaped in and shaping contemporary Japan, this course will offer an entry into theories of gender studies and sexuality, and also introduce tools to critically analyze cultural differences manifested in the issues of gender and sexuality while at the same time learning more about Japanese society and your own society. Moving between historical and contemporary definitions of gender, sexuality, and family to look at change and continuity of gendered life ways in Japan, the course is divided into five sections addressing issues of: 1) Defining Gender and Gender Stereotypes; 2) Gender and Social Institutions; 3) Gender Construction / Performance; 4) The Politics of Sexuality and Identity; and 5) Gender and “Marginality.” In each section we investigate cultural constructions of gender, sexuality, and family and key themes that revolve around them: identity, class, morality and life course in contemporary Japan. At the end of each section we will take time to reflect on gender and sexuality in Asia more broadly. Class sessions will consist of lecture sessions devoted to explaining the readings in context and tutorial sections for facilitating active discussions and student presentations. Assignments for the course will ask students for active participation and weekly discussion questions, a reflective mid-term essay, and a final exam.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course students will be able to demonstrate knowledge of social theories and approaches to gender and sexuality, discern stereotypes from social facts, and contextualize and analyze gendered and gendering socio-cultural phenomena. Students will also be able to construct analytical essays, give power-point presentations, and lead academic discussions.

courses.course_syllabus:
Course Syllabus
Course Description English:
Japanese management is characterized by a combination of indigenous cultural influences, early postwar borrowing of ideas and creative development. Because of the success of Japanese economic development, Japanese management has become a unique and important field by itself. While Japanese management was much emulated in the 1980s and 1990s, it has also adapted and evolved according to chronological phases in its development. Changing Japanese economic needs, demographic shifts and evolving trends/lifestyles/habits seem to push Japanese management into a creative knowledge-based phase which is covered in the last section of this course. In the final analysis and in terms of application, one may develop comparative perspectives after taking this course, both internally within the different chronological phases of Japanese management as well as externally with other forms of management techniques.
This course introduces the historical and social development of present Japanese management practices and systems. It aims to equip students with better understanding of Japanese business people, to establish mutual understanding, and to help students learn to collaborate with staff from Japan so as to achieve common objectives.
The organization of the course is chronological starting from Japanese management’s basic features to revisiting its sustained and continued applicability and finally to cutting edge contemporary ideas. It is a broad survey intended for class participants with no prior knowledge of management theories or Japanese studies beyond the usual terms encountered in the mass media and some acquisitions of new terminologies. It does not pretend to be comprehensive but gives participants a broad and foundational understanding of J-management augmented by selected case studies. It is broad and foundational in the sense that the course can be divided into three phases from the basic features to recent case studies and then to the nuts and bolts of contemporary ideas.

Course Description
Japan's postwar economic development has become a model by itself, characterized by state-led development, unique Japanese economic features, fast-growth and is also in the midst of reforms and demographic adaptation to cope with new challenges. To understand contemporary Japanese economy, it may be just as important to study its developmental phases. After the fast-growth period, while observers are keen to see how Japan will cope domestically with its long recession. Both internal and external economic dynamics interact to form the basis of Japan's economy. No prior knowledge of economics is needed beyond the usual understanding of terms that one typically finds in the mass media (ie layman understanding). It utilizes some the materials of some of the most influential economists in Japan including Nakamura Takafusa (University of Tokyo) and cutting-edge works by Western scholars. The course is a survey that does not pretend to be exhaustively but nevertheless gives its participants a firm foundation in understanding Japanese economic development. The course can be broadly divided into three main sections of historical development, contemporary developments and case studies.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: The History of 20th Century Japan

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

courses.description: This course explores modern Japan, which underwent perhaps the most striking transformation of any country in the modern world. Narrowly escaping colonization, Japan transformed into one of the most important imperial and economic powers in the world. Modern Japan is also doubly fascinating for a comparative take on the great themes of modern global history: the social upheavals and transformations of capitalism and democracy, the rise and fall of modern imperialism, the experience of total war, and the spread of a mass consumer culture. This course examines the invention of new traditions and the construction of a new national identity, the rise and fall of empire, the devastation of World War II, and the astonishing postwar economic growth and puzzling stagnation in contemporary times. This course explores how people in Japan have dealt with the dilemmas of modernity that challenge us all.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the semester, students will have achieved:
(1) Understand the major dynamics and trends of modern Japanese history
(2) Deepen their understanding of modern and contemporary Japanese society
(3) Learn to write logical and coherent historical papers
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Course Introduction; Meiji Restoration
This will explore the arrival of the “Black Ships” and the reasons behind the overthrow of the Shogunate.
Week 2: Civilization and Enlightenment
This week deals with Japan’s Meiji-era cultural/intellectual Westernization.
Week 3: Constructing the Meiji State
This week explores the creation of Japan’s new political structure and the fruits of Japan’s modern revolution.
Week 4: “Rich Nation, Strong Army,” and the Making of Japan’s Empire
This week deals with the logic and goals of becoming an empire in the age of imperialism.
Week 5: State and Society in Japan’s Imperial Democracy
This week investigates the move toward party leadership, and the linkages between state and society in Taishō era Japan.
Week 6: The Roaring ‘20s, and Tensions in Modern Life
This week explores the tensions brought about by capitalism and Japanese modernity.
Week 7: Crisis of Capitalism and Empire
This week explores the Great Depression and the “Manchurian Incident.”
Week 8: Japan at War
This week deals with the “China Incident,” Japanese ultra-nationalism, and the move toward all-out war in the Asia-Pacific. It also deals with daily life during wartime.
Week 9: America’s Japan: Occupation and Aftermath
This week studies the American Occupation of Japan and its aftermath.
Week 10: Cold War Realignments and the Conservative Political Resurgence
This week highlights the remarkable conservative resurgence in Japan, and its battles with the progressive left.
Week 11: Postwar Economy and Society
This week deals with the growth of a middle class and meritocratic society in the postwar years, and the remarkable “economic miracle.”
Week 12: A New Global Power?
This week discusses the Plaza Accord, the Japanese economic bubble, and the birth of Japan as a new global power in the 1980s.
Week 13: The Lost Decades, 3.11, and Beyond
This week has students cover important issues from the last 25 years of Japanese society.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Asia at War
courses.description: World War II remains the most total and bloodiest conflict in world history. Fought on multiple fronts on three continents, the war witnessed a complex mesh of ideologies and war aims. It wrought unparalleled destruction and targeted civilians to an unprecedented degree. It has been the only war to date in which atomic weapons were used. The war pitted empires against each other and led to the fall of many of those global empires. This course will focus on World War II in Asia. It uses Japanese history as a window into global processes, and also places the war in its proper regional context. Beginning with World War I, this course journeys through the crisis of East Asian international relations in 1920s and 1930s to the outbreak of a multi-front war in East and Southeast Asia. It considers the war’s impact on empires and nations, soldiers and victims, and peoples throughout the region. And it explores the legacies that remain visible across the region today.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand the causes and legacies of World War II in Asia. In the process, they will learn the ways in which the war helped shape the contemporary world.
Read academic works and learn to clearly articulate the main arguments of academic writing.
Engage confidently in class-time debates and improve their argumentative reasoning.
Write research papers that make use of primary source documents (the documents analyzed can be in any language).
Understand historical events from multiple perspectives, and become more critical of primary source documents.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction and Course Outline
Week 2: World War I and Empires at War
This week focuses on World War I in Asia, the emergence of Japan as a world power during the wartime years, and Japanese wartime imperialism in China and the Asia-Pacific.
Week 3: Aftermath of War: The Washington System and its Discontents
This week centers on the dramatic global postwar rejection of the diplomacy of imperialism and war that was symbolized by the "Washington System". It was this system that Japan would seek to change and then overthrow in the 1930s.
Week 4: The Global Depression and Crisis in Manchuria
This week focuses on the issues leading to the Manchurian Incident of September 1931 and the renewed Japanese imperialism of the 1930s.
Week 5: Ultranationalism, Insubordination, Rebellion, and the Question of Fascism
Japan's renewed imperialism was accompanied by ultranationalism in society and insubordination and even rebellion with the military. This class will use these issues to question the nature of Japanese "facism".
Week 6: Japan and China: Toward Total War
This week focuses on the lead up to and the initial stages of Japan's total war in China from 1937.
Week 7: Japan Lashes Out! The Attacks of December 8, 1941
This week will focus on the beginning of the Pacific War, or the so-called War for Greater East Asia. Students will have a fun group activity for the majority of the class to try to avoid the war from happening!
Week 8: Asia Under Japan
This week will show how Japan sought to rule much of Asia, and how its efforts changed throughout the course of the war.
Week 9: The War in Everyday Life
This week will show the impact the war had on daily life in Japan.
Week 10: Learning How to Die
This week will focus on the cultural history of fighting a losing war, and how that led Japanese government and mass media to enshrine death as a meaningful way to fight.
Week 11: Endgame: The Japanese Surrender
This week will center on the events surrounding the Japanese surrender, including the controversial decisions to use firebombing and atomic weaponry as weapons of war.
Week 12: From War to Peace
This week will focus on how the war's end reshaped Japan, its empire and the region.
Week 13: The War in Retrospect: Legacies and Memories
This final week will continue to show the extraordinary legacies of the age of total war on both Japan and Asia.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: The Construction of Japanese Ethnic and Cultural Identity
courses.description: Though extensively influenced by ancient China, Japan has developed into one of the world’s most distinctive cultures. Japan’s remote geographic location made it possible for changes to come relatively slowly, and except for the postwar reform, most innovations resulted from the voluntary adoption of foreign cultures rather than external pressure. This course discusses how Japanese civilization, i.e. the Yamato nation, and the Japanese language were formed. How Japanese society arose through the localization of foreign cultures will be one of the major themes covered. Efforts will be made to identify nation-wide characteristics, if any, and investigate how they were cultivated over the centuries. Special attention will be paid to the similarities that can be found between the two major social reforms in modern Japanese history, i.e. the Meiji Restoration and postwar reform, and to the question of how these reforms influence Japan society today.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Features of the Japanese Language: A Cultural and Historical Analysis
To discuss how Japanese people i.e. Jomon people, Yayoi people and Yamato nation and the Japanese language were possibly formed.
2. The Early Horse-rider Theory and the Modified Hypothesis
To discuss the pros and cons of the popular and yet controversial theory for analyzing how Yamato nation was formed.
3. Features of Japanese Cultural History
To introduce the features of Japanese cultural history i.e. the separation of power and authorities, top-down social reforms, cultural advancement by external stimulations, etc. How the Edo government ruled the people (only samurai and farmers will be focused) will also be discussed.
4. Essence of Japanese Aesthetics
To introduce makoto, aware, okashi, wabi & sabi, iki.
5. Zen and Japanese Tea Ceremony
To introduce how Japanese tea ceremony was developed in a Japanese way.
6. Rice Growing in Edo Period and the Correlations between the Government and the Farmers
To introduce how Japanese government helped and exploited the farmers in Edo period.
7. Double Structure of Japanese People’s Mentality in Meiji Period
To introduce how the country advanced but the people were confused in Meiji period.
8. The Ideal and Reality of the Peace Constitution Drawn up after the Second World War
To introduce how the Postwar Japan was reformed and changed under the overwhelming influence by the GHQ.
9. The Thematic Concerns of Imamura’s Ballad of Narayama and Its Implication to the Understanding of Japan Society
To analyze Imamura’s thematic concerns in the Ballad of Narayama, and discuss its implication to the understanding of Japan society.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Everyday Life and Cultural Representation in Modern Japan

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 405

courses.description: This course aims at examining the dynamics between everyday life, modernity, and the representation of tradition in modern Japan from two different perspectives. Part One of the course introduces students Japanese responses to the idea of modernity, and the cultural transformation and social crisis over the course of Japan’s modernization. Part Two examines the continuation of, rapprochement with, and appropriation of traditional elements in the cultural lives of contemporary Japan.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to be able to critically discuss the ideas and effects of modernization in Japan in different aspects, such as gender, urban space, and environmental problems.
2) Students are expected to be able to critically analyze the representation of tradition in contemporary Japan.
3) Students are expected to develop their own critical angles to examine and interpret the meanings of Japanese cultural products, such as films, novels, and anime.
4) Students are expected to strengthen their reading skills in a range of academic disciplines, including anthropology, cultural studies, and modern history.

courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to speak to the instructor about their views of the course. In addition, students will be asked to fill out a mid-term survey after about four weeks into the semester and a University course evaluation at the end of the semester.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Japanese Grammar
courses.description: This course will focus on the grammatical structure and characteristics of the Japanese language. Students will renew their grammatical understanding of Japanese and analyze it from a systematic point of view. Some of the major parts of speech, such as nouns, adverbs, adjectives, Rentaishi, particles, including their significance, characteristics, and functions will also be covered and discussed.

Students are expected to be able to describe the grammatical structure and the characteristics of the Japanese language

Students are expected to be able to use nouns, adverbs, adjective,

, and particles, in appropriate and accurate ways.

courses.description: This course is mainly designed for students who want to achieve a high standard of Japanese language proficiency in vocabulary, grammar, listening and reading. Specifically, it will focus on strategies aimed at language improvement for achieving a publicly recognized standard (which is equivalent to JPLT N2 level ), as well as encouraging students to be responsible for managing their own language learning. Coursework will include vocabulary, grammar, listening and reading assignments. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration. 3) read and understand upper-intermediate level Japanese articles (from daily articles to official documents) by using different kinds of reading skills.
4) understand a wide range of spoken Japanese (from daily conversations to formal speech) by using different kinds of listening skills.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: English-Japanese Translation
courses.description: This course equips students with foundational skills for translating English into Japanese and introduces the basic knowledge necessary for improving quality. Texts are drawn from current events in newspapers, magazines, social media, academic journals and books. Advisory: Not for students who have studied for one year or more in Japan.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisites: JASP2460 or 2480 or equivalent competence in Japanese
Not for students who have taken JASP4180,4310,4330,4350,4360,4370,4380,4390,4420,4440,4450,4510,4520
courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand the strength and weakness of a variety of translation methods.
Recognize text types and their conventions, formulate best approaches for translating different types of texts, and reflect on strategies for problem solving.
Develop the ability to reflect on the process of translation.
Apply linguistic and sociocultural knowledge to produce translations from English to Japanese.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to English-Japanese translation
Week 2: Words, cultural-specific items, abstract nouns, neologisms, and
gairaigo
Week 3: Lexical collocations, idioms, and multi-character and abbreviated compounds
Week 4: Personal names, terms of address, and organisation names and job titles
Week 5: Numeric expressions, inclusive expressions, and time expressions
Week 6: Orthographical and typographical issues
Week 7: Verb/noun orientation, verb-based pseudo-topics, topicalization and situation focus
Week 8: Rhetorical hedging and indirectness
Week 9: Register, tone, emphasis, repetition, and parallelism
Week 10: Spoken form, dialogue, interactional particles, dialect, gendered speech, and respect language
Week 11: Group presentation
Week 12: Group presentation
Week 13: Review and conclusions
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Translation practice: Students will be assigned one piece of text (250 words) to practice their translation skills.
Translation project: Each student will produce a translation of a set text of 800 words accompanied by a 400-word reflective commentary outlining the student’s
self-reflections on the strategies and procedures that s/he has employed for this translation project
. The commentary may also address such questions as:
How is
your experience of doing this project related to what you have learned about translation during this course? In what way(s) has this project been beneficial for you? How might it be beneficial in the future, both for you and for others?
Presentation: Students will work in groups of 3-4 members on a translation exercise relating to a topic of their choosing. Each group will translate an English text of 1500 words into Japanese and present to the whole class a summary of the work they have undertaken in the process of planning the project, researching the topic and translating the text.
In general, the summary should
introduce the text
(What is the text you chose to translate? Why did you choose this text? What do you particularly like about this text? What does your reader need to know about the author of the text? What does your reader need to know about the context from which the source text emerged?, etc.), and
address the group’s choice of translation approach(es) and difficulties encountered in the exercise in both general terms and specific to English – Japanese translation
(What are the conventions of the chosen text type? What similar texts did you use as your reference? What difficulties did you anticipate in the translation? What theoretical approach to translation did you follow? What translation strategies and techniques did you adopt and why? Did you encounter cultural problems in your translation? What process did you follow in preparing the translation? How did you solve the anticipated problems? Are you satisfied with your solutions? Where are you dissatisfied? Who or what sources helped you? How did you organize your work as a group?, etc.).
Active participation: Assessed on each student’s engagement in class discussions, groupwork and practical translation tasks in-class.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Through Media
courses.description: This course is designed for students who want to improve their language proficiency and vocabulary through various media sources available in the Hong Kong market. Focus will be put on encouraging students to be responsible for managing their Japanese language learning through resources available in their daily life. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration. Advisory: Not for students who have studied for one year or more in Japan.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisites: JASP1040, 2460 or 2480 or equivalent competence in Japanese
Not for students who have taken JASP4180,4310,4330,4350,4360,4370,4380,4390,4440,4450,4510,4520
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Deepen basic skills to access and understand media information in Japanese.
- Familiarise the style and structure of Japanese that commonly used in media.
- Widen student’s understanding of the cultural context of those vocabularies used in media products, such as in Mixi,
facebook, twitter, YouTube, etc.
- Enable students to have the ability to express their opinion on the information in mass media.
- Develop student’s ability on understanding “Emergency" information such as for typhoon, earthquake and traffic information,
and so be ready to travel or study in Japan.
courses.course_syllabus:
The semester will be planned according to the following areas:
- Emergency Information: learning and understanding the instructions and vocabularies used in different occasions of
emergency.
- Written Style and Spoken Style: compare the basic structure and grammatical patterns used in formal news articles and in
casual conversations in newspaper, TV drama and films.
- Communication in Internet: enhance the ability to communicate with native Japanese through internet using various internet
tools. Assess and review the grammar used in internet.
- Listening: using audio-visual materials so that students can learn about the cultural background of those daily
conversational topics and current issues.
- Workshop: students will be asked to do a small project to be presented in class, so to deepen the knowledge learned and
enhance their communication ability.
The lecturer will make frequent reference to the information in various media like news, TV drama, film, internet etc.
courses.feedback_evaluation:

courses.description: This course investigates the relationships between Japan and Hong Kong from historical and sociological perspectives, focusing on the activities of the Japanese in Hong Kong from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. Main topics for lecture and discussion include early Japanese residents in prewar Hong Kong, Hong Kong under Japan's occupation, Japan-Hong Kong economic and cultural ties, the Japanese community in Hong Kong, the Japanese popular culture boom in Hong Kong and the Hong Kong culture in Japan. Guest lecture, panel discussion, study tour and debate may be organized to supplement lectures and discussion.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Youth Cultures in Asia
courses.description: Youth cultures have played a critical role in shaping Japanese public attitudes and debates, consumer movements, and institutions in the postwar period. Japanese youth-oriented popular cultures are currently reshaping the cultural landscape across much of Asia. This course explores Japan's youth cultures and introduces the diversity of youth experiences in Japan. It further allows students to explore the influence of Japanese youth cultures in other Asian societies. The course encourages students to compare youth cultures in Japan with that of China, Hong Kong, and North America. The course will also consider the rise of transnational youth cultures based on movements of people, ideas, and images across national borders. It will explore the emergence of a Japan influenced youth popular culture in Asia as well as the particular local contexts in which the experiences of youth take on meanings for individuals.

Analyze the nature and influence of the knowledge from Japanese Studies
Evaluate how Japanese culture influence the generation’s ideology
Understand how concepts of Japanese-ness are established and developed
Elaborate how Japanese culture is localized and metamorphosed after participations of different stakeholders and local agencies.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Anthropology of Japanese Popular Culture
courses.description: This course offers an advanced seminar on Japanese popular and mass culture from anthropological perspectives. Thus this is not a survey course of different kinds of popular culture in Japan, but rather this course requires us to theoretically engage in social theories of popular/mass culture and analyze interpretations of meanings and forms of particular “popularly massified” socio-cultural phenomena in Japan.The course first provides literature on the major classical and critical theories of the “culture industry” in Europe as well as the formation of mass society in Japan. Next, we will analyze the forms and meanings of the diverse, popularly massified culture of production and consumption by examining anthropological works on Japan. Specifically, this course examines the issues of popular culture and mass culture through four different spheres: culture industries, media consumption, material culture and fandom, and globalization. Through analyzing these four spheres, the course also traces the thematic issues of gender, class, and cultural politics in the context of modernization and globalization. These issues provide the underlying structure and symbols that demonstrate how anthropologists approach a particular representation of complex popularized cultural movements under late capitalism.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course students will be able to demonstrate knowledge of social theories and approaches to popular/mass culture and the culture industry. Students will also be able to construct analytical essays, give power-point presentations, and lead academic discussions.
