courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: World War Two on Japanese, Chinese and American Screens
courses.description: This course aims to explore the possible motivations and political backgrounds underlying the production of films that are related to WWII in East Asia, following the end of the Cold War, that is, during and after the 1990s. The intention is to analyze whether the demise of the Cold War has provided a more favorable time for Japan, China and the US to re-examine WWII in a fresh light. The year 1990 marks a watershed for geopolitics. In that immediately prior to and after 1990, the world witnessed many historical events still thought of as the most significant in recent history, even today. Such events as regards East Asia include the Tiananmen Incident, the burst of Japan’s bubble economy, the disintegration of the USSR and the rise of China. Security concerns among China, Japan and the US changed following 1990 in that Russia is no longer thought of as being a common threat of such primary importance as was the case with its predecessor state, the USSR. There is today a renewed sense of nationalistic assertiveness that can be seen in disputes in and amongst Japan, China and the US over history, territories, military expansion and in conflict over trade between these economic giants. At the same time, in the last twenty years, there have been frequent productions of movies related to WWII in East Asia, on events where differing views of history cause controversy, such as the Nanjing Massacre, Pearl Harbor and Hiroshima. There is therefore importance in investigating to what extent these movies are a reflection of such nationalistic sentiment, as well as the extent to which the WWII theme in filmmaking for a popular market is a tool for groups harboring specific political and ideological agendas. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. Students are required to choose a related topic at the beginning of the course and present his/her ideas in the last two lessons. Based on the presentation, students are required to submit a paper of about 3,000 words in the end of the semester, indicating their appreciation and understanding of the lecture materials and required readings.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. be familiar with the political influence in the formation of popular culture, in particular why the images and narratives of WWII continue to play such a significant role in shaping public consciousness and people’s senses of identity
2. be familiar with the Japanese, Chinese and American historical collective consciousness in respect of WWII in East Asia
3. be able to contextualize and analyze selected movies and present a well-organized analysis in a written or oral presentation
4. be able to make connections between the past and present phenomena of the world
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson 1: Orientation
This lesson introduces the objectives, significances and learning approaches of the course.
Lesson 2 and 3: Japan’s Contested Views on War Responsibilities
These two lessons explore how the Japanese reinforce and overemphasize their image as the victim of WWII; and on the other hand, how they address the war responsibilities of Emperor Hirohito and of their own country.
Lesson 4 and 5: Japanese and Chinese Representations of the Tokyo Trials
These two lessons discuss how the Tokyo Trials are used as a channel through which to express anti-Americanism by some Japanese and Chinese movies.
Lesson 6 and 7: Nanjing Massacre and the Politics of Memories
These two lessons examine how the Nanjing Massacre is politicized in a self-righteousness manner; and with a view to national mythmaking by many Chinese, Japanese and Americans.
Lesson 8 and 9: Political Agenda of CCP’s Commemorations
These two lessons investigate how the Chinese Communist Party uses anniversaries and commemorations to promote their political messages.
Lesson 10 and 11: Heroism/Anti-Herosim in Post-911 American Cinema
These two lessons analyze how heroism in American WWII movies has been transformed before and after the 911 Incident.
Lesson 12 and 13: Presentation of Students
Students are required to present their topics and ideas in a 20-minute oral presentation with the use of power point.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Language and Society
courses.description: This course explores both linguistic structures and sociolinguistic features of the Japanese language. The first half of the course will discuss sociolinguistic features in Japanese language such as the history of linguistic exchanges in the kanji (Chinese character) and lexicon between China and Japan among other case studies, application of linguistic politeness expressions and word formation. The second half of the course will discuss the major linguistic features in Japanese language such as its grammatical structures and semantic features in the Japanese language. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course. This course is designed for students who have completed elementary Japanese language courses and are interested to know more about the structure of the Japanese language and its sociolinguistic characteristics. At the completion of the course, students will have gained a better understanding of the structure of the Japanese language in general situations and will have learned how to apply language usage according to Japanese linguistic social norms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Students taking this course should possess Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPT) N2 certificate or having Japanese language proficiency equivalent to JLPT N2 level; or should have completed JASP2480/3340.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1 Students should acquire knowledge of the Japanese language structure
(i.e. sentence structure, characteristics of words and sound system)
2 Students should be able to describe the major characteristics of kanji, kanji words and loanwords in the Japanese
language
3 Students should be able to explain the characteristics and usage of the linguistic politeness in the Japanese
language
4 Students should be able to explain the main characteristics of the lexicon and word formation in Japanese
language
5 Students should acquire knowledge of syntactic and semantic structures in Japanese language
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1 Introduction to the structure of Japanese language
In this section, the structure of the Japanese language will be discussed. It analyzes sentence structure, characteristics of words and sound systems in the Japanese language.
Topic 2 The development of kanji, kanji words and loanwords in the Japanese language
In this section, the historical overview of kanji in Japanese language will be discussed. Various types of reading (goon, kanon and tôon – different forms of reading in Japanese) in Japanese kanji will be introduced. In addition, the history of how kanji words and loanwords are developed in the Japanese language will be discussed.
Topic 3 Expressions of linguistic politeness in the Japanese language
In this section, the category and various forms of phrases expressing linguistic politeness will be discussed. It includes honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.
Topic 4 Lexicon and words formation in the Japanese language
In this section, the word type and word formation in Japanese language will be discussed. Special attention will be given to:
a. compound words
b. onomatopoeia (words signifying sounds and gestures)
Topic 5 Syntax in the Japanese language
In this section, the syntax structure in Japanese language will be discussed. Some of the highlighted items include:
a. tense and aspectual system
b. verb classification
c. “Mondaina Nihongo” (problematic Japanese usage)
Topic 6 Semantics in Japanese language
In this section, the semantic structure in Japanese language will be discussed. Methodology such as semantic analysis, differentiation of connotative meaning and denotative meaning, and idiomatic expressions will be introduced.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Philosophy
courses.description: This course aims to understand and analyze Japanese philosophy, which is an important topic for reflecting on the roots of Japanese intellectual history and contemporary philosophical debates. Three areas will be discussed: 1) Japanese intellectual traditions such as those found in Buddhism, Confucianism and Shinto/Native Studies thought; 2) modern Japanese philosophers such as Nishida Kitaro, Kuki Shuzo and Watsuji Tetsuro; and 3) contemporary Japanese thought: Karatani Kojin, Post-311 philosophy, etc.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to understand basic concepts of Japanese philosophy, and their influence on traditional, modern and contemporary Japanese culture. They can critically read texts written by Japanese philosophers, and analyze Japanese cultural phenomena from a philosophical perspective.
courses.course_syllabus: 1. Introduction 2. Traditional Japanese thought: Buddhism, Confucianism, Shinto and Native Studies 3. Modern Japanese philosophy: Nishida Kitaro, Kuki Shuzo, Watsuji Tetsuro 4. Contemporary Japanese thought: Karatani Kojin, Post-311 philosophy 5. Conclusion

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Popular Religions in China, Japan and Korea
courses.description: This course explores the East Asian philosophical and religious traditions of Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism both from an internal perspective – how did each tradition represent its own values, goals, practices and methods of devotion – and external perspectives – how did the traditions spread across the East Asian subcontinent, assimilate with traditional cultural norms, and influence art and architecture. In addition to these so-called “three teachings,” we also discuss popular religion in South-east Asia, new combinatory religions such as Aum Shinrikyo and Cao Đài, and the impact of East Asian religious ideas on the West. We will also address religion in modern times, understanding how traditions continue to carve out roles for themselves in a secular world.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) understand commonalities and differences between values and their representations in different religious traditions,
2) comprehend how religious texts were composed and addressed the interests of their readership,
3) consider the influence of religion on visual media,
4) apprehend the historical arc of religions from India and China through Korea, Japan and across the globe.
5) Consider how we use various forms of historical data in combination to compose a narrative about the past.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction and Buddhism as Idea
What core concepts, such as “emptiness,” “Two-truth Theory,” and the “Fourfold Noble Path,” are common to Buddhist traditions? How did the Mahāyāna idea of the “bodhisattva” differ from earlier forms of Buddhism?
Week 2: Buddhist Scripture
What literary devices, such as simile and parable, are central to Mahāyāna literature? What is the role of “skillful means”? How do these literary and conceptual developments compare with early Buddhist texts?
Week 3: Human Relations as Ritual
What is the role of the“holy rite” or “sacred ceremony” within the Analects? Can Confucianism simultaneously be religious and humanistic?
Week 4: The Daoist Body
How did Daoism evolve from a political philosophy to a method of internal cultivation? How was the body envisioned as a territory governed by a divine bureaucracy for meditative purposes?
Week 5: Empty Mind
How did Chan/Zen present itself as a“special transmission outside the scriptures”? What are “kōan” (public cases), and how are they used to instruct students?
Week 6: The World as Religious Text
How does Esoteric Buddhism use mantra (chants), mudra (gestures), and mandala (visualization) to theorize Buddhist practice as a form of communication?
[Part 2: Religions in Practice]
Week 7: The Silk Road and the Spread of Buddhism to Korea
By what means did Buddhism spread from China to neighboring countries on the Korean peninsula? What sorts of indigenous religions did Buddhism encounter there?
Week 8: Challenges to Mainstream Japanese Religion
How and why did the medieval Pure Land movements in Japan segregate themselves from mainstream Buddhist thought and practice? How does Japanese “sectarianism” differ from more pluralistic approaches to Buddhism elsewhere in East Asia?
Week 9: Warrior Dramas and the Way of the Samurai
How were Buddhist ideas central to the content and theories of Japanese medieval literature? How did Buddhist ideas become a basis for the conduct and morals of Japanese warriors (samurai)?
Week 10: Chinese Religion as Communal Activity
How does popular religion in China today work to connect village temples that provide services, raise funds, and mobilize communities to participate in collective rituals, sometimes described as a “second government?”
Week 11: Buddhist Art and Architecture
How did Buddhism influence visual and material culture in East Asia in the realms of painting, garden design, and architecture?
Week 12: New Religions of Asia
What are some of the newest religions in East Asia since the 19th c., particularly in Vietnam and Japan? How are they perceived, and what positive and negative impacts have they made on society? How have traditional religious institutions adapted to new religions’ widening influence?
Week 13: Zen and the Western World/Conclusions
How has East Asian religion impacted popular culture in the West? What are some of the pervasive images of Buddhism in Western literature and film?
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to speak to the instructor about their views of the course. In addition, students will be asked to fill out a mid-term survey after about four weeks into the semester and a University course evaluation at the end of the semester.

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408

courses.description: Although Japanese language learners usually take the “standard language” of Japanese as the learning target, there are many dialects in Japan and they can represent the characteristics of culture in that particular area. This course introduces the structure of dialect by comparing the differences between the “standard language” and one representative example of Japanese dialects: the Kansai dialect. Students will learn how Kansai dialect reflects the culture and customs of the Kansai area through the perspectives of sociolinguistics. This course will use multi-media resources such as novels, T.V. soap dramas as teaching materials to illustrate the daily usage of the Kansai dialect.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: students should have one year studying experience in Japan or equivalent competence in Japanese.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to be able to identify and describe the characteristics of the language usage in Japanese media by studying the Kansai dialect which is one of the most well-known representative dialects in Japan.
2. Students are expected to be able to identify various types of dialects by comparing the differences among various dialects and the standard language.
3. Students are expected to be able to use the approach of sociolinguistic analysis and find out how culture influence the language usage.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction to Japanese dialectology
Negative form of Verbs in Kansai dialect
Week 2-3 Osaka dialect and Chinese language
Expressions for prohibition and permission in Kansai dialect

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Anthropology of Japan
courses.description: This course examines Japanese culture through anthropological perspectives. The course will consider how people in Japan experience family life, work and intimate relationships. It also covers cultural ideals such as the self, gender roles and aesthetic forms. The lectures will explain how anthropological perspectives have been used to study Japan. The course encourages students to consider how anthropological methods and approaches can be used to study Japan as well as their own societies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken JASP5615
courses.learning_outcomes:
to identify different anthropological approaches to Japan
to reflect critically upon different anthropological and other social science approaches to Japan
to reflect on larger questions of meaning and perspective

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Advanced English-Japanese Translation
courses.description: This course introduces some of the key concepts in translation theory and focuses on their application to English to Japanese translation practice. The course provides students who have a solid knowledge of basic Japanese with a practical experience of translation and aims to develop their translation skills to a high level of proficiency. Students will work with a wide range of text types, become familiar with different translation techniques, and develop intellectual perspectives on the activity of translation. Texts are drawn from various sources including news media, internet, business communication, academic literature, fiction and films. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: One year of study in Japan or equivalent competence in Japanese
courses.learning_outcomes:
Apply linguistic and sociocultural knowledge to produce translations from English to Japanese.
Recognize text types and their conventions, formulate best approaches for translating different types of texts, and reflect on strategies for problem solving.
Develop the ability to reflect on the process of translation.
Learn to analyze the relationship between translation and culture.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to translation studies
Week 2: Skills and knowledge necessary to work as a successful translator
Week 3: Translation strategies, methods, approaches, and different degrees of freedom (literal, free, semantic, communicative, or adaptation)
Week 4: Techniques for translating different text types (literary, academic, business, and media)
Week 5: Techniques commonly adopted in English – Japanese translation (omission, expansion, and changing parts of text)
Week 6: Difficulties specific to English – Japanese translation (rhetorical devices, proverbs, and idioms)
Week 7: Methods for translating culture-specific items (transcription, naturalization,
localization,
and cultural equivalent)
Week 8: Translation and culture, interlingual translation and intralingual translation
Week 9: Computer-aided human translation and machine translation
Week 10: Oral dimension, consecutive interpreting and simultaneous interpreting
Week 11: Group presentation
Week 12: Group presentation
Week 13: Review and conclusions
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Assignment: Students will be assigned one
piece of homework (500 words)
to practice their translation skills.
Translation project: Each student will produce a translation of a
set text of 1000 words accompanied by a 400-word reflective commentary
outlining the student’s
self-reflections on the strategies and procedures that s/he has employed for this translation project
. The commentary may also address such questions as: How is your experience of doing this project related to what you have learned about translation during this course? In what way(s) has this project been beneficial for you? How might it be beneficial in the future, both for you and for others?
Presentation: Students will work in groups of 3-4 members on a translation exercise relating to a topic of their choosing. Each group will translate an English text of 2000 words into Japanese and present to the whole class a summary of the work they have undertaken in the process of planning the project, researching the topic and translating the text.
In general, the summary should
introduce the text
(What is the text you chose to translate? Why did you choose this text? What do you particularly like about this text? What does your reader need to know about the author of the text? What does your reader need to know about the context from which the source text emerged?, etc.), and
address the group’s choice of translation approach(es) and difficulties encountered in the exercise in both general terms and specific to English – Japanese translation
(What are the conventions of the chosen text type? What similar texts did you use as your reference? What difficulties did you anticipate in the translation? What theoretical approach to translation did you follow? What translation strategies and techniques did you adopt and why? Did you encounter cultural problems in your translation? What process did you follow in preparing the translation? How did you solve the anticipated problems? Are you satisfied with your solutions? Where are you dissatisfied? Who or what sources helped you? How did you organize your work as a group?, etc.).
Active participation: Assessed on each student’s engagement in class discussions, groupwork and practical translation tasks in-class.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Advanced Spoken Japanese
courses.description: The course aims to enhance both speaking and listening abilities. Selected readings on contemporary Japanese or local social issues will be used to practice the expressions and exchange of ideas. Classroom activities will include exchanging ideas, discussion, speech, etc. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: One year of study in Japan or equivalent competence in Japanese
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
・discuss some abstract contents in Japanese.
・discuss topics in Japanese not only in daily life level but also in business level for the future career.
・make discussion supported with evidence.
courses.course_syllabus:
In order to achieve this goal, this course is divided into three stages. In the first stage, students are required to present their points of views with reasoning after given a topic without referring to any materials. In this stage, students will be asked to be paired-up. They have to try to tell their points of views. and at the same time, they learn other’s opinions as well.
In the second stage, students will be asked to find subjective materials to support their objective ideas. They are asked to collect information that they need to support their thoughts and their partners are asked to do the same in order to argue their point of views with facts and references.
In the final stage, by using what have been learnt in the first and second stages, students will be asked to debate on abstract topics such as "Environmental Protection and Urban Development", "pros and cons of surrogate mother system" and " Problem of male and female students living together in the college dorm". Debate topics will be discussed and chosen by students so as to increase their interests and motivation on the course.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Advanced Japanese Writing
courses.description: This course aims to provide techniques of writing in Japanese to students through the perspective of communication, enabling them to produce a high standard of writing which is easy to read and understand. Students will learn discourse patterns, vocabulary and expressions in Japanese to help them in writing reports, e-mails and other daily communication tasks. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: One year of study in Japan or equivalent competence in Japanese
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to know the techniques of producing high standard of writing in Japanese to meet the needs of daily communication tasks such as formal and informal e-mails.
2. Students are expected to learn cross-cultural communication differences in Japanese.
3. Students are expected to know how to write academic paper in Japanese.

Week 13 Test

courses.description: This course enables students to assemble and analyse research materials collected during their year of study in Japan or their third year of study when they take the local study scheme. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors in their final year of attendance.The Field-Research Based Project, a requirement for all JAS major students, is completed over the course of four years. Preparation for the project begins in year one and year two when students take JAS1010, JAS1050, and JAS1090. In these courses, students gain familiarity with contemporary Japanese politics, economy, culture and society. Students also learn to identify and evaluate academic arguments, locate academic sources, cite sources properly, and identify and assess basic social science and humanities research methods. In the third-year of study, students decide on their research topic and methods, and appropriately apply research methods to collect data for the project. Students who are in the fourth year of study, should have completed data collection and should be writing the paper. Students should have made efforts to speak, read, and write Japanese to achieve their research aims. Students are expected to have used Japanese for activities such as requesting assistance, conducting interviews, creating questionnaires, surveying media sources, and conducting literature reviews. The final-year project completed during the required courses JAS4601 and JAS4602 is thus the final product of the previous three years’ of preparation in both Japanese studies and Japanese language.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students complete their research paper based on the data they collected during their year in Japan, and using the skills and knowledge attained during year one. Students are expected to (a) become knowledgeable about and critically analyze a specific topic in Japanese studies, (b) master the skills of researching and writing a research paper in English, and (c) gain proficiency in communicating the results of data collection and analysis.
Skills learned through the final-year project are transferable to their future workplaces and graduate school work. In job interviews, job applications, on their resumes, and in graduate school applications, JAS graduates who have successfully completed the project may be able to state the following:
1. They are capable of planning, developing, and implementing a long-term (two-year) project.
2. They are capable of approaching people to make new contacts and creating networks.
3. They are capable of collecting experts’ research results written in Japanese, Chinese, and English. They are capable of analyzing this material, making reasoned conclusions, and clearly communicating the results of your analysis orally and in writing.
4. They are capable of collecting original data, analyzing, and communicating the results of their analysis.
courses.course_syllabus: Students will submit a mid-year draft of the paper, approximately 15 to 25 pages. The final paper, approximately 30 to 40 pages will be sumitted before the end of the semester. In addition, students will make an oral presentation on a chosen date.

courses.description: This core course is designed to prepare students to conduct postgraduate research in Japanese Studies. It introduces key conceptual and methodological approaches from different disciplines. Students are encouraged to critically evaluate various approaches and consider how they may be integrated for their particular research projects. The course teaches the analytical skills and methodological tools that will allow students to develop and execute a research project. These skills include research design, data collection, analysis and developing writing strategies.

2) articulate the basic trends in the social development of modern Japan.

courses.description: This course explores methods and approaches used by anthropologists in studying Japan. The course provides students with an anthropological framework for research on Japan. It introduces village studies, urban studies, and recent studies of popular culture, gender and mass society. The course will also introduce theoretical approaches and concepts used by anthropologists studying Japan. Students will be encouraged to focus on a particular aspect of Japanese society using selected anthropological approaches.

2) use anthropological approaches to discuss basic trends in the social development of modern Japan.

courses.description: This course introduces approaches to studies of gender in Japan. The focus will be primarily on sociological and anthropological studies of gender. The course takes a historical perspective, encouraging students to consider how and why ideological constructions of gender have changed over time in specific social, political and economic contexts. It considers the relationship between social ideals, institutional structures and everyday experiences of gender. The course also examines current gender relations and roles in a variety of arenas of life such as families, corporations, communities, political groups, schools, and in the mass media.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the conclusion of the course, students will be able to:
1) identify and analyze major trends in sociological and anthropological studies of gender in Japan
2) articulate and discuss how ideological constructions of gender have changed over time in different social, political, and economic contexts.
3) knowledgeably discuss gender relations and roles in a variety of institutions such as family, companies, communities, and schools.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Special Topics in the Japanese Political Economy
courses.description: This course investigates major debates as related to the Japanese political economy in the global age. It is designed to enhance a theoretical and empirical understanding of the Japanese political economy and business at advanced level. It incorporates the necessary tools for a critical analysis of the existing political-economic system by familiarizing students with advanced theories, research design and methodology. By taking this course, students will gain an in-depth knowledge of Japanese politics, economics and business utilizing appropriate approaches and analytical tools.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the conclusion of the course, students will have:
1) achieved mastery of advanced theoretical and empirical understanding of Japanese political economy and business
2) obtained the necessary tools - such as advanced theories, research design and methodology - to critically analyze Japan’s political economic system
3) acquired indepth knowledge of Japanese politics, economics, and business

courses.description: Selected linguistic differences between Japanese and other languages including English will be introduced in this course. Cross-linguistic variation in phonology, syntax and semantics will be analyzed to compare languages from the perspectives of Language Typology and Universal Grammar.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Special Topics in Linguistic Research and Japanese Language Teaching
courses.description: This course examines different issues in linguistic research that is particularly applicable to foreign language teaching and learning. Focus is put on the interface of theoretical analysis and their implications for Japanese language teaching and learning as a foreign language.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) Students will be able to have an overview of those key linguistic research topics related to teaching Japanese as a foreign language.
(2) Students will be able to apply the methodologies and findings from those linguistic studies discussed in this course to their own linguistic study.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Teaching Japanese as a Second Language
courses.description: This course introduces and discusses various concepts in teaching Japanese as a second language which include course design, the procedures of handling classroom activities, the proper usage of teaching materials and teaching tools, method of assessment of students, etc. These discussions are essential to students who will pursue their career goals in Japanese language teaching upon graduation. Moreover, the course will also examine methods used in teaching foreign language with a focus on Japanese language education.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students should acquire the technique of course design and teaching plan preparation.
2. Students should be able to apply various methods to teach the four essential skills in language acquisition, namely, reading, writing, listening and speaking.
3. Students should be able to explain those significant grammatical points in an easy-to-understand way.
4. Students should acquire the technique of classroom management.
5. Students should be able to apply the cultural elements to assist foreign language teaching.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Linguistics
courses.description: The aim of this course is to enable students to understand linguistic aspects of Japanese. The course content includes pronunciation, writing system, vocabulary, and grammar. This course is suitable for everyone who wishes to organize and enrich their knowledge about the Japanese language for academic and pedagogical purposes, such as proficient Japanese speakers and prospective or ongoing Japanese teachers.

courses.description: This course explores Japanese communication patterns and the relationship between Japanese language, society, and culture. The course considers how the use of language reflects social contexts and human relationships. It also explores the factors that shape the success or failure of communicating in Japan, and how Japanese communication patterns compare with those of other cultures.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Tradition and Modernity in Contemporary Japan
courses.description: This course aim at analyzing the relationship between traditional culture and modern society in Japan. It explores key cultural and social concepts in historical contexts, and considers how ideas and institutions have changed over time.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the relationship between historical social-cultural institutions and modern formations of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, leisure, and religion.
2) Students will be able to identify and critically assess different ways in which traditional culture is interpreted in modern Japan.
2) Students will be able to critically assess different approaches to understanding Japanese society and culture.
3) Students will have improved their academic essay writing and research skills.

Week 1: Introduction: Images of Japan
Week 2: Perspectives on Tradition and Modernity
Week 3: Interpretations of Japanese Traditions
Week 4: Education
Week 5: Work and Workplaces
Week 6: Home and Family
Week 7: Gendered Experience
Week 8: Power, Politics, and Media
Week 9: Leisure and Popular Culture
Week 10: Religion
Week 11: Japan in Global Perspective
Week 12: Student Presentations
Week 13: Conclusions

courses.title: Chinese-Japanese Interpretation and Translation
courses.description: This course aims to enable students proficient in Japanese and Chinese (mainly Putonghua but also Cantonese) to critically understand interpreting professions in terms of language, cognition, and ethics, and develop their practical techniques in interpreting Chinese into Japanese, suitable to prospective or ongoing professional interpreters as well as upper advanced language learners wishing to obtain in-depth knowledge of both languages. Different types of discourses will be used to acquire basic but versatile skills of consecutive interpretation by stages. Trainings cover retention, anticipation, paraphrasing, reproduction, information precession, note taking, sight translation, and possibly simple simultaneous interpretation. Special attention is drawn to contrasting structural and socio-cultural between Chinese and Japanese languages.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Advanced English-Japanese Translation
courses.description: This course introduces some of the key concepts in translation theory and focuses on their application to English to Japanese translation practice. The course provides students who have a solid knowledge of basic Japanese with a practical experience of translation and aims to develop their translation skills to a high level of proficiency.Students will work with a wide range of text types, become familiar with different translation techniques, and develop intellectual perspectives on the activity of translation.Texts are drawn from various sources including news media, internet, business communication, academic literature, fiction and films. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students of MPhil-PhD Japanese Studies & MA Japanese Studies
Exclusion= JASP4380
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Apply linguistic and sociocultural knowledge to produce translations from English to Japanese.
2. Recognize text types and their conventions, formulate best approaches for translating different types of texts, and reflect on strategies for problem solving.
3. Develop the ability to reflect on the process of translation.
4. Learn to analyze the relationship between translation and culture.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to translation studies
Week 2: Skills and knowledge necessary to work as a successful translator
Week 3: Translation strategies, methods, approaches, and different degrees of freedom (literal, free, semantic, communicative,
or adaptation)
Week 4: Techniques for translating different text types (literary, academic, business, and media)
Week 5: Techniques commonly adopted in English – Japanese translation (omission, expansion, and changing parts of text)
Week 6: Difficulties specific to English – Japanese translation (rhetorical devices, proverbs, and idioms)
Week 7: Methods for translating culture-specific items (transcription, naturalization, localization, and cultural equivalent)
Week 8: Translation and culture, interlingual translation and intralingual translation
Week 9: Computer-aided human translation and machine translation
Week 10: Oral dimension, consecutive interpreting and simultaneous interpreting
Week 11: Group presentation
Week 12: Group presentation
Week 13: Review and conclusions
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Assignment: Students will be assigned one piece of homework (500 words) to
practice their translation skills.
• Translation project: Each student will produce a translation of a set text of 1000 words
accompanied by a 400-word reflective commentary outlining the student's selfreflections
on the strategies and procedures that s/he has employed for this
translation project. The commentary may also address such questions as: How
is your experience of doing this project related to what you have learned about
translation during this course? In what way(s) has this project been beneficial for you?
How might it be beneficial in the future, both for you and for others?
• Presentation: Students will work in groups of 3-4 members on a translation exercise relating to a topic of their choosing. Each group will translate an English text of 2000words into Japanese and present to the whole class a summary of the work they have undertaken in the process of planning the project, researching the topic and translating the text.
In general, the summary should introduce the text (What is the text you chose to translate? Why did you choose this text? What do you particularly like about this text? What does your reader need to know about the author of the text? What does your reader need to know about the context from which the source text emerged?, etc.), and address the group's choice of translation approach(es) and difficulties encountered in the exercise in both general terms and specific to English – Japanese translation (What are the conventions of the chosen text type? What similar texts did you use as your reference? What difficulties did you anticipate in
the translation? What theoretical approach to translation did you follow? What translation strategies and techniques did you adopt and why? Did you encounter cultural problems in your translation? What process did you follow in preparing the translation? How did you solve the anticipated problems? Are you satisfied with your solutions? Where are you dissatisfied? Who or what sources helped you? How did you organize your work as a group?, etc.).
• Active participation: Assessed on each student's engagement in class discussions,
groupwork and practical translation tasks in-class.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Dialectology
courses.description: Although Japanese language learners usually take the “standard language” of Japanese as the learning target, there are many dialects in Japan and they can represent the cultural characteristics in that particular area. This course introduces the structure of dialect by comparing the differences between the “standard language” and one representative example of Japanese dialects: Kansai dialect. Students will learn how dialects reflect the culture and society in Japan through the perspectives of sociolinguistics. This course will use multi-media resources such as TV variety programs, dramas and comedy shows as teaching materials to illustrate the daily usage of dialects.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies.
Students should have passed JLPT N1 or above.
Students who took JASP4100 (Japanese Dialectology) are NOT allowed to take JASP5524 “Japanese Dialectology”.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to be able to identify and describe the characteristics of the language usage in Japanese media by studying the Kansai dialect which is one of the most well-known dialects in Japan.
2. Students are expected to be able to identify various types of dialects by comparing the differences between dialect and standard language.
3. Students are expected to be able to use the approach of sociolinguistic analysis and find out how culture and society influence language usage.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Theory and Methods in Japanese Studies
courses.description: This course is intended to introduce and broaden the understanding of contemporary Japanese society from the modern period to the contemporary period. By introducing some of the theories and methodological approaches that have been used to examine Japanese society, students will learn, and critically discuss perspectives of history, sociology, anthropology and cultural studies and media analyses. Moreover, utilizing a variety of readings, lectures, and film, students will engage in a multi-level analysis of contemporary Japan.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: The course has a number of major learning outcomes. (1) Students are expected to critically discuss Japanese society using a variety of theories and methodological approaches. (2) Students are expected to be able to clarify and articulate thoughtful and well-founded opinions from a comparative perspectives. (3) Students are expected to develop the ability to engage critically in academic discussions through weekly contributions to in-class discussions and presentations. (4) Students are expected to develop their research skills through a short-term research project that includes a written assignment and in-class presentation.

The course covers the period from 1600, when the Tokugawa Shogunate began its two-and-half-century rule over Japan, to 1945, when the Asia-Pacific War ended with Japan’s surrender. It examines the political, economic, social and cultural transformation of Japan during the early modern and modern periods.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Thematic Study of Japanese Films
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with an in-depth understanding of the development of Japanese film. It discusses major theories, models, approaches and scholarly writings on Japanese film related to media studies, cultural studies and gender studies. Through the class discussion and presentation, student will be able to critically appraise and analyze Japanese film.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Articulate the basic theoretical concepts of film studies.
- Appraise the ideologies, practices and trends of film industry in Japan.
- Analyze and think critically about the issues in Japanese cinema.
- Understand the history and diversity of Japanese movie creations.
- Assess the impacts of Japanese film and understand major issues and debates related to cinema in Japan internally as well as its relation to the world.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Literature in Historical Perspective
courses.description: This course introduces students to the main themes of Japanese literature from the ancient to the modern period. The texts covered include poetry, diaries, drama, and fiction. The social and cultural context in which the work was produced will be discussed. Each work will be discussed within larger trends in Japanese literature.Students are expected to have completed all reading assignments before class so that the assigned reading may be discussed during the class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to understand the basic themes of traditional and modern Japanese literature. They can critically read texts written by Japanese writers, and analyze the context of the works.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Anthropology of Japan
courses.description: This course examines Japanese culture through anthropological perspectives. The course will consider how people in Japan experience family life, work and intimate relationships. It also covers cultural ideals such as the self, gender roles and aesthetic forms. The lectures will explain how anthropological perspectives have been used to study Japan. The course encourages students to consider how anthropological methods and approaches can be used to study Japan as well as their own societies.

courses.learning_outcomes:

2. to reflect critically upon different anthropological and other social science approaches to Japan
3. to reflect on larger questions of meaning and perspective

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Contemporary Japan-China Relations
courses.description: This course examines the regional and global implications of Sino-Japanese relations. Students will explore Sino-Japanese relations from political, economic, security and cultural perspectives from 1850 onwards. Using the prisms of history and international relations theories, studies will gain a deeper understanding of developments, challenges and opportunities that exist between Japan and China. Topics to be covered include but are not exclusive to: 1)General Introduction to International Relations Theories; 2) Sino-Japanese relations; 3) Sino-Japanese War(s); 4) Post WW II Relations; 5) Yasukuni Shrine & Textbook controversies; 6) War Memory; and 7) Future directions for Sino-Japanese Relations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to be able to critically discuss Sino-Japanese relations and how they are related to changes in the international system.
(2) Students are expected to be able to clarify and articulate thoughtful and well founded opinions in a comparative context related to Sino-Japanese relations.
(3) Students are expected to develop their research skills through a short in-term research project that includes a written assignment and oral presentation.
(4) Students are introduced to a variety of research methodologies such as text analysis, public discourse analysis, qualitative methodology including interviewing skills etc.
(5) Students are expected to develop the ability to engage critically in academic discussions through an in-class presentation using video and power point technologies.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Philosophy in Japanese Culture
courses.description: This course focuses on specific topics in Japanese culture. In this semester it will introduce Japanese philosophy, which is an important topic for understanding the root of Japanese culture. Three areas will be discussed: 1) traditional Japanese thought such as Buddhism, Confucianism and Shinto/Native Studies thoughts; 2) modern Japanese philosophers such as Nishida Kitaro, Kuki Shuzo and Watsuji Tetsuro; and 3) topics related to Japanese philosophical thoughts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to understand basic concepts of Japanese philosophy, and their influence on traditional and modern Japanese culture. They can critically read texts written by Japanese philosophers, and analyse Japanese cultural phenomena from a philosophical perspective.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Traditional Japanese thought: Buddhism, Confucianism, Shinto and Native Studies
3. Modern Japanese philosophy: Nishida Kitaro, Kuki Shuzo, Watsuji Tetsuro
4. Special topics: Karatani Kojin, Japanese philosophy and pilgrimage, Japanese philosophy and innovation
5. Conclusion

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Cultural Identity
courses.description: Regardless of the overwhelming influence from ancient China, Japan has developed into one of the world’s most distinctive cultures. Japan’s peripheral geographic location made it possible for gradual changes to occur based on its own internal needs. Except for the postwar reform, most Japanese innovations resulted from the voluntary adoption of foreign cultures rather than external pressure from foreign countries.This course explores how the Yamato nation and the Japanese language were formed based on hypotheses in related fields. How Japanese society arose through the localization of foreign cultures will be dealt with from a cultural historical point of view. Attempts will be made to identify nation-wide characteristics, if any, and investigate how they were cultivated over the past centuries. Special attention will be paid to the similarities that can be found between the two major social reforms in modern Japanese history i.e. the Meiji Restoration and postwar reform. The course also discusses how these reforms influence modern Japan society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies and MA in Japanese Studies;Not for students who have taken JASP2550, JASP3110, JASP3120, JASP5060 - Ethnic Identity in Japan
courses.course_syllabus:
1. A Cultural Historical Analysis of the Features of the Modern Japanese Language
2. The Exploration of the Possibility of How the Yamato Nation and the Japanese Language Were Formed
3. An Introduction to the Distinctive Features of Japanese Cultural History
4. Essence of Japanese Aesthetics based on Works of Classical Japanese Literature
5. Zen and Japanese Tea Ceremony: The Development of Japanese Samurai’s Cultural Identity
6. Rice Cultivation in Edo period: The Infiltration of Samurai’s Impact into Farmers’ Daily Practice and Mentality
7. Double Structure of Japanese People’s Mentality in Meiji period
8. The Ideal and Reality of the “Peace Constitution” Drawn up after the Second World War
9. The Thematic Concerns of Imamura’s Ballad of Narayama and Its Implication to the Understanding of the modern Japan Society

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Management: Work, Culture, and Capitalism
courses.description: Japanese economic growth has been one of the most remarkable success stories of the past century. Japanese business practices have emerged from Japan’s particular path to modernization and its capitalist conditions. What are the characteristics of Japanese capitalism? In what ways do capitalist economies differ from one another in their social organization, institutional embeddedness, gendered relations, and modes of governance? What are the challenges of such differences for management and economic performance in a competitive global economy? How have Japanese corporations responded to the processes of globalization and neoliberalization? In tackling these questions, we will analyze the issues of industrialization, globalization and neoliberalism as well as a broad range of topics, including those related to labor, industrial organization, the theory of the firm, management, gender, and economic reforms in Japanese society. Finally by examining the inside of the Japanese corporate world, we also learn some of the “techniques” that Japan had/has invented and introduced to the world. Thus this course challenges the common and presentist views of “Japanese business” and “Japanese corporations.” Instead it introduces the complex development of Japanese capitalism from the early 19th century to the present and examines ongoing transformations within Japanese capitalism.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated MPhil-PhD in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: The course has a number of major learning outcomes. (1) Students are expected to critically read the materials and discuss a variety of concepts and issues to analyse work, culture, and capitalism in Japan. (2) Students are expected to be able to recognize the external and internal changes and continuities regarding Japanese business practices and management strategies. (3) Students are expected to articulate well-founded opinions on Japanese business and use concrete evidence. (4) Students are expected to synthesize the issues from class readings, lectures, and presentations to formulate clear answers for the mid-term essay and final essay assessments.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: The Global Japanese
courses.description: This course examines Japanese migrants and communities in diverse locations such as East Asia, Oceania, Europe, and Americas. Through tracing historical experiences of Japanese emigrants (Nikkeijin) and exploring their transnational cultural practices, students will develop a picture of Japan’s changing roles in a globalized world from an aggressive colonizer to an economic superpower to a shrinking society. Topics may include the variegated roles of Japanese migrants in settler communities and colonial societies, gendered communities of practice, transnational networks and communication, linguistic and culinary hybridity, and Japanese migrants’ contribution to the global spread and dissemination of Japanese popular culture

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Anthropology of Japanese Popular Culture
courses.description: This course offers an advanced seminar on Japanese popular and mass culture from anthropological perspectives. Thus this is not a survey course of different kinds of popular culture in Japan, but rather this course requires us to theoretically engage in social theories of popular/mass culture and analyze interpretations of meanings and forms of particular "popularly massified" socio-cultural phenomena in Japan.The course first provides literature on the major classical and critical theories of the "culture industry" in Europe as well as the formation of mass society in Japan. Next, we will analyze the forms and meanings of the diverse, popularly massified culture of production and consumption by examining anthropological works on Japan. Specifically, this course examines the issues of popular culture and mass culture through four different spheres: culture industries, media consumption, material culture and fandom, and globalization. Through analyzing these four spheres, the course also traces the thematic issues of gender, class, and cultural politics in the context of modernization and globalization.These issues provide the underlying structure and symbols that demonstrate how anthropologists approach a particular representation of complex popularized cultural movements under late capitalism.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Language and Society
courses.description: This course explores both linguistic structures and sociolinguistic features of the Japanese language. The first half of the course will discuss sociolinguistic features in Japanese language such as the history of linguistic exchanges in the kanji (Chinese character) and lexicon between China and Japan among other case studies, application of linguistic politeness expressions and word formation. The second half of the course will discuss the major linguistic features in Japanese language such as its grammatical structures and semantic features in the Japanese language. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course. This course is designed for students who have completed elementary Japanese language courses and are interested to know more about the structure of the Japanese language and its sociolinguistic characteristics. At the completion of the course, students will have gained a better understanding of the structure of the Japanese language in general situations and will have learned how to apply language usage according to Japanese linguistic social norms.

For students of MPhil-PhD Japanese Studies & MA Japanese Studies
Exclusion = JASP3700
courses.learning_outcomes:
1 Students should acquire knowledge of the Japanese language structure
(i.e. sentence structure, characteristics of words and sound system)
2 Students should be able to describe the major characteristics of kanji, kanji words and loanwords in the Japanese
language
3 Students should be able to explain the characteristics and usage of the linguistic politeness in the Japanese
language
4 Students should be able to explain the main characteristics of the lexicon and word formation in Japanese
language
5 Students should acquire knowledge of syntactic and semantic structures in Japanese language
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1 Introduction to the structure of Japanese language
In this section, the structure of the Japanese language will be discussed. It analyzes sentence structure, characteristics of words
and sound systems in the Japanese language.
Topic 2 The development of kanji, kanji words and loanwords in the Japanese language
In this section, the historical overview of kanji in Japanese language will be discussed. Various types of reading (goon, kanon
and tôon – different forms of reading in Japanese) in Japanese kanji will be introduced. In addition, the history of how kanji words
and loanwords are developed in the Japanese language will be discussed.
Topic 3 Expressions of linguistic politeness in the Japanese language
In this section, the category and various forms of phrases expressing linguistic politeness will be discussed. It includes honorific
expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice
and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between
such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.
Topic 4 Lexicon and words formation in the Japanese language
In this section, the word type and word formation in Japanese language will be discussed. Special attention will be given to:
a. compound words
b. onomatopoeia (words signifying sounds and gestures)
Topic 5 Syntax in the Japanese language
In this section, the syntax structure in Japanese language will be discussed. Some of the highlighted items include:
a. tense and aspectual system
b. verb classification
c. "Mondaina Nihongo" (problematic Japanese usage)
Topic 6 Semantics in Japanese language

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Philosophy
courses.description: This course aims to understand and analyze Japanese philosophy, which is an important topic for reflecting on the roots of Japanese intellectual history and contemporary philosophical debates. Three areas will be discussed: 1) Japanese intellectual traditions such as those found in Buddhism, Confucianism and Shinto/Native Studies thought; 2) modern Japanese philosophers such as Nishida Kitaro, Kuki Shuzo and Watsuji Tetsuro; and 3) contemporary Japanese thought: Karatani Kojin, Post-311 philosophy, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students of MPhil-PhD Japanese Studies & MA Japanese Studies
Exclusion= MA students cannot be enrolled in both JASP5625 and JASP5619 within their study period in the Programme
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to understand basic concepts of Japanese philosophy, and their influence on traditional, modern and contemporary Japanese culture. They can critically read texts written by Japanese philosophers, and analyze Japanese cultural phenomena from a philosophical perspective.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Media and Technology in Japan
courses.description: This course traces the historical development of communication media including print media, audio recordings, film, television, internet, social media, and artificial intelligence bots, and examines the functions and limitations of each communication method as well as the impact of media systems on Japanese society and culture. Special attention is given both to the role of mass media in reflecting and projecting society and the characteristics of media practices as a central force in the shaping of culture. Through study of major institutions in Japan’s media industry, students will explore and critique the powerful collaboration of media, technology, and business, and develop an informed, ethical view of the impact that these institutions continue to have on community, national, and global life.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:
Understand key moments and developments in the history of Japanese media and technology from early modern times to the present.
Analyse the cultural, social, and political factors that have shaped the development and reception of media technologies in Japan.
Evaluate the global impact of Japanese media technology on various industries and cultural spheres outside Japan.
Apply critical thinking and interdisciplinary approaches to the study of communication media in Japan
, especially in relation to the shift from analog to digital cultures.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Asia and Asianism in Modern Japanese History
courses.description: “Asia” is one of the core concepts of Japanese cosmopolitanism. In the modern era (19th-20th century), when the world dynamics were changing drastically, Japanese intellectuals tried to break away from the old East Asian order centered on China and put forward a new worldview to build up a modern Japanese national consciousness and regional order. The discussion of “Asia” is one of the specific attempts. This is an exploratory course that analyzes various Asian discourses from the perspectives of the history of Sino-Japanese relations, the history of East Asia, and the history of the world and discusses the process of change in Japan's understanding of Asia and the world from different perspectives, including history, ideology, politics, economics, literature, and culture.The lectures cover the Asian (East Asian) understanding of China and Japan in ancient times, the Asian view and worldview of Japan in modern times, the interaction between the late Shogunate thinkers and the times, the activities and evolution of different Asianist organizations in the Meiji period, such as the Shinyasha (振亞社), the Koya-kai (興亞會), the Asia Society (亞細亞協會), the Toho-Kyokai (東邦協會), the Genyōsha (玄洋社), and the Kokuryū-kai (黑龍會), as well as the Asian views and interactions between the important thinkers of China and Japan such as Sun Yat-sen, Li Dazhao, Fukuzawa Yukichi, Okakura Tenshin, and others. It also explores the views of post-war Japan, China, Korea, the United States, India, and other countries on the Asian/East Asian conflicts and alliances, discussing the possibilities and challenges of the integration of post-war Asia or East Asia.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Independent Research Project

meetings.instructor:
Professor Jeremy Avrum YELLEN, 
Professor Lynne Yukie NAKANO

courses.description: This course enables MA students to independently investigate a research topic with the assistance of a supervising professor. The student is expected to propose the topic herself/himself and may proceed if the topic is approved by a suitable supervisor. The topic may be in any field that is related to Japanese Studies if the supervisor’s consent is obtained. The research question, research methods, and length of the paper should be decided at the start of the course through discussion and agreement between the student and the supervisor. The number and frequency of meetings between the student and the supervisor should be decided at the start of the course after discussion and agreement between the student and the supervisor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the conclusion of this course, students will have:
1. produced an original research paper.
2. mastered skills of conducting and writing a literature review and analyzing data.
3. developed their knowledge in a specific area of Japanese studies based on their interest.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Contents/fundamental concepts
Select research topic
Conduct literature review
Data collection and analysis
Independent work
Students are expected to select a topic
with the guidance of his/her
supervisor.
Students are expected to take the initiative to conduct and write a literature review.
Students will collect original data if appropriate or analyze existing data in an original way.
Students will work independently and will take the initiative to meet with their supervisors regularly to facilitate the writing project.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to speak to the instructor about their views of the course. In addition, students will be asked to fill out a mid-term survey after about four weeks into the semester and a University course evaluation at the end of the semester.
courses.required_readings:
Readings will depend on the research topic chosen, and will be decided upon by the teacher and the
student. The student should conduct a literautre review to select appropriate readings, with the
guidance of the supervisor.

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japan-China Intellectual and Cultural Exchange in the Early Modern Period
courses.description: This course is designed to examine the introduction and localization of Chinese culture in Tokugawa Japan (1603-1868) through reading of primary sources and important academic writings in English, Japanese and Chinese. Issues such as the redefinition and appropriation of Confucian concepts, the interaction between Chinese learning and nativist learning, Chinese legends in Tokugawa Japan and the uses of Chinese terminology in Tokugawa historiography will be investigated through close reading of Tokugawa texts and small-group discussion.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in the Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D Programme in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) study important works on Tokugawa intellectual history and Sino-Japanese relations.
(2) acquire basic skills in reading classical Chinese and Japanese in the Tokugawa style.
(3) prepare for Ph.D research.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part One (week 1-4): Basic readings on Tokugawa Intellectual History
Part Two: (week 5-8): Basic readings on Sino-Japanese relations in the early modern period.
Part Three (week 9-12): Readings of Tokugawa texts.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course Evaluation
courses.required_readings: (1) Maruyama Masao, Studies in the Intellectual History of Tokugawa Japan (Princeton University Press, 1974)
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Wai-ming Ng, The I Ching in Tokugawa Thought and Culture (University of Hawai'i Press, 2000)
(2) Herman Ooms, Tokugawa Ideology (Princeton University Press, 1985).
(3) Marius Jansen, China in the Tokugawa World (Harvard University Press, 1992)

courses.subject: JASP
courses.title: Japanese Culture and Society in Regional and Global Perspectives
courses.description: This course examines the theoretical and conceptual approaches in studying Japanese society and culture from regional and global perspectives. The course considers changes in Japanese society and culture domestically as well as in relation to regional and global contexts. It explores the commonalities and differences in the experiences of globalization, demographic changes brought about by economic development, changes to the political system and civil society, as well as consumption and lifestyles in Japan and other Asia-Pacific regions and areas, including but not restricted to the US, China, Hong Kong. It also investigates how theoretical and methodological approaches have changed over time in examining Japanese society and culture due to increasing contributions made by scholars in comparative studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in the Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D Programme in Japanese Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of the course, students will be able to:
- identify and critique theoretical and conceptual approaches to Japanese society and its interactions with other societies.
- apply different methodological approaches to studying Japan and its interactions with other societies and cultures.
- critically analyze comparative approaches in the study of Japan.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Week 1 Japanese and their identity
Read: Oguma, Eiji. A Genealogy of Japanese Self-Images. Melbourne: TransPacific Press. 2002.
Tanaka, Stefan. Japan’s Orient: Rendering Pasts into History. Berkeley: University of California Press. 1993.
* Week 2 Contemporary Japanese society and its family system
Read: Holloway, Susan D., Women and Family in Contemporary Japan. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. 2010.
Tsuya, Noriko and Larry Bumpass (eds). Marriage, Work and Family in Comparative Perspective: Japan, South Korea, and the United States. Honolulu: University of Hawaii Press.
* Week 3 An aging society
Traphagan, John W. and John Knight (eds). Demographic Change and the Family
in Japan's Aging Society. NY: SUNY Press. 2003
* Week 4 Japanese society and socioeconomic developments
Brinton, Mary. Lost in Transition: Youth, Work, and Instability in PostIndustrial
Japan. New York: Cambridge University Press. 2011.
Schoppa, Leonard J., Race for the Exits: The Unraveling of Japan's System of
Social Protection. Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press. 2006
* Week 5 Social change and civil society
Read: Kingston, Jeff. Japan's Quiet Transformation: Social Change and Civil
Society in 21st Century Japan. NY and London: Routledge. 2004
* Week 6 Minorities in Japanese society
Read: Weiner, Michael, Japan's Minorities: The Illusion of Homogeneity. London and NY: Routledge. 2009.
* Week 7 Multi-ethnicity and multiculturalism
Read: Lie, John, Multiethnic Japan. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. 2004
* Week 8 Japan society and political system
Read: Neary, Ian. The State and Politics in Japan. Cambridge, Oxford and Boston:
Polity Press. 2002.
* Week 9 Japan’s consumption and lifestyles in Asia
Read: Chua, Beng Huat (ed.). Consumption in Asia: Lifestyles and Identities. NY
and London: Routledge. 2000.
* Week 10 Japan in the world
Read: Miyoshi, Masao and Harry Harootunian (eds). Japan in the World. Durham
NC: Duke University Press. 1993
Pyle, Kenneth. Japan Rising: The Resurgence of Japanese Power and Purpose.
New York: Public Affairs. 2007.
* Week 11 Comparative perspectives: Ageing in Asia
Read: Goodman, Roger and Sarah Harper (eds). Ageing in Asia. NY and London:
Routledge. 2008
* Week 12 Cultural exchanges
Read: Auslin, Michael. Pacific Cosmopolitans: A Cultural History of US-Japan
Relations. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. 2011.
Iwabuchi, Koichi. Recentering Globalization: Popular Culture and Japanese
Transnationalism. Durham: Duke University Press. 2002.
Week 13
